The gray downward triangles are the WISE 12 and 22 <i>&#956;</i>m upper limits while the black downward triangles are the <i>Herschel</i>/PACS upper limits.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=11&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201936727\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n</table></div></p>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S24\"></a>4.2. Gas mass and depletion time</h3>\n<p>Given that we detect high-J transitions of CO, i.e. CO (5&#8594;4) and CO(4&#8594;3), deriving a gas mass requires that uncertainties in the spectral line energy distribution (SLED) must be forded in with the uncertainty on the adopted <i>&#945;</i><sub>CO</sub> value. Therefore, we first use the [CI] flux measurement to derive the H<sub>2</sub> mass. Indeed, <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R15\">Bothwell et al. (2017)</a> showed that [CI] and CO(2&#8722;1) have similar kinematic properties in a sample of dusty star-forming galaxies, suggesting that [CI] traces the same gas component as low-<i>J</i> CO emission. Furthermore [CI] as a gas mass tracer is far less affected by metallicity than CO (for instance, <a name=\"InR14\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R14\">Bothwell et al. 2013</a>), although it does require an assumption that the line is optically thin.</p>\n<p>We follow the prescription of <a name=\"InR88\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R88\">Papadopoulos &amp; Greve (2004)</a>:</p>\n<p><a name=\"FD1\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><a name=\"img_eq25\"></a><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19-eq25.gif\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(1)</span></span></p>\n<p>with</p>\n<p><a name=\"FD2\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><a name=\"img_eq26\"></a><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19-eq26.gif\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(2)</span></span></p>\n<p>and where <i>h</i>&#8242; = 0.75, the Einstein <i>A</i>-coefficient <i>A</i><sub>10</sub> = 7.93 &#215; 10<sup>&#8722;8</sup> s<sup>&#8722;1</sup>, <i>X</i><sub>CI</sub> = 3 &#215; 10<sup>&#8722;5</sup>, and <i>Q</i><sub>10</sub> = <i>Q</i><sub>10</sub>(<i>n</i>,&#8198;<i>T</i><sub><i>k</i></sub>) depending on <i>n</i> and <i>T</i><sub><i>k</i></sub> the gas density and temperature (<a name=\"InR122\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R122\">Wei&#223; et al. 2003</a>; <a name=\"InR89\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R89\">Papadopoulos et al. 2004</a>). Assuming the abundance and excitation factors of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R1\">Alaghband-Zadeh et al. (2013)</a>, we find <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19-eq27.gif\"></span>, with <i>&#956;</i> the magnification factor due to lensing, which yields <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19-eq28.gif\"></span> = 2.65 &#177; 0.73 &#215; 10<sup>11</sup> <i>M</i><sub>&#8857;</sub>, assuming a 36% helium contribution and no significant atomic H component as in <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R124\">Yang et al. (2017)</a>. Converting the <i>L</i><sub>IR</sub> to SFR we obtain <i>&#956;</i>SFR = 1.82 &#215; 10<sup>4</sup> <i>M</i><sub>&#8857;</sub> yr<sup>&#8722;1</sup> and derive a depletion time as:</p>\n<p><a name=\"FD3\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><a name=\"img_eq29\"></a><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19-eq29.gif\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(3)</span></span></p>\n<p>finding <i>t</i><sub>dep</sub> = 14.4 &#177; 4.7 Myr. This is a short depletion time highly suggestive of a high-efficiency, bursty star formation, typical for SMGs (for instance, <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R5\">Aravena et al. 2016</a>).</p>\n<p>However, as the gas mass measurement obtained from CI depends on the assumption that CI is optically thin, to provide an independent check, we also derive the gas mass using the CO(4&#8722;3) line (Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#T4\">4</a>). Assuming <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19-eq30.gif\"></span> (<a name=\"InR23\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R23\">Carilli &amp; Walter 2013</a>), we obtain <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19-eq31.gif\"></span>. Using <i>&#945;</i><sub>CO</sub>&#8196;=&#8196;0.8 <i>M</i><sub>&#8857;</sub>/K km s<sup>&#8722;1</sup> pc<sup>2</sup>, we obtain <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19-eq32.gif\"></span> <i>M</i><sub>&#8857;</sub>, which is consistent with the estimate obtained from CI. This gas mass estimate yields a depletion time of 17.2 &#177; 2.2 Myr. Although the uncertainty of this estimate does not reflect the uncertainty in the <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19-eq33.gif\"></span> ratio and <i>&#945;</i><sub>CO</sub> assumptions, it is consistent with the value obtained from CI.</p>\n<p>Finally, we use the dust mass as a third independent gas mass indicator:</p>\n<p><a name=\"FD4\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><a name=\"img_eq34\"></a><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19-eq34.gif\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(4)</span></span></p>\n<p>with <i>&#948;</i><sub>GDR</sub> the gas-to-dust mass ratio. We assume here the average <i>&#948;</i><sub>GDR</sub> of 56 (&#177;28) obtained by <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R124\">Yang et al. (2017)</a> for a sample of lensed SMG. We obtain <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19-eq35.gif\"></span> = 6.0 &#177; 3 &#215; 10<sup>11</sup> <i>M</i><sub>&#8857;</sub> and from this a <i>t</i><sub>dep</sub> of 32.9 &#177; 18.7 Myr. Thus, using the dust mass, we obtain a larger, yet still small value of the depletion time indicating a starbusting phase. Using the <i>&#948;</i><sub>GDR</sub> obtained from the ALESS sample (<a name=\"InR105\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R105\">Simpson et al. 2014</a>; <a name=\"InR113\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R113\">Swinbank et al. 2014</a>), 75 &#177; 10, would yield a depletion time of 44.0 &#177; 5.9 Myr. However, the sample of lensed SMGs of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R124\">Yang et al. (2017)</a> has physical properties that are close to those of RV4, therefore we use the gas mass obtained using the gas-to-dust ratio of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R124\">Yang et al. (2017)</a> in the following. These derived values are short, comparable to those of other starburst galaxies, and pointing towards a rapid starburst episode. We note that when computing the depletion times, we assume that the magnification <i>&#956;</i> is the same for the gas component and the IR produced by star-formation since we cannot make a detailed investigation of differential magnification with the data in hand.</p>\n<p>Given the good coverage of RV4&#8217;s IR SED with 6 data points from 250 <i>&#956;</i>m to 3 mm observed (44 to 524 <i>&#956;</i>m, rest frame), we derived the dust mass of RV4 from SED modeling. We used an updated version of the model of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R47\">Draine &amp; Li (2007)</a> (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R48\">Draine et al. 2014</a>), which is physically motivated and takes into account the different contributions from the dust heated in PDR and the dust heated by more evolved stars. As an alternative, <a name=\"InR100\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R100\">Scoville et al. (2016)</a> proposed a method useful when only one observation is available in the Rayleigh-Jeans part of the SED but it is one that relies on assumptions based on, for example, dust temperature, which can lead to broad uncertainties (<a name=\"InR8\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R8\">Berta et al. 2016</a>). Given our good coverage of both the peak of the IR emission and the Rayleigh-Jeans part of the SED, we prefer to rely on our measurement based on SED modeling. However, for comparison, we compute the gas mass of RV4 obtained by the <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R100\">Scoville et al. (2016)</a> method and obtain 7.7 &#177; 2.0 &#215; 10<sup>11</sup> <i>M</i><sub>&#8857;</sub>, uncorrected from magnification. This leads to a depletion time of 42.8 &#177; 11.1 Myr.</p>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S25\"></a>4.3. Gas density</h3>\n<p>In this section, we use the computed IR, CO(4&#8722;3), and [CI](1&#8722;0) luminosities of RV4 obtained from EMIR (summing the emission of all three blobs) to investigate its gas properties. First, we present in Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#F12\">12</a> (top panel) the relation between [CI](1&#8722;0) to IR ratio and the IR luminosity. For comparison, we add a selection of data from the literature (<a name=\"InR121\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R121\">Walter et al. 2011</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R1\">Alaghband-Zadeh et al. 2013</a>; <a name=\"InR10\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R10\">B&#233;thermin et al. 2016</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R15\">Bothwell et al. 2017</a>; <a name=\"InR76\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R76\">Lu et al. 2017</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R21\">Ca&#241;ameras et al. 2018</a>; <a name=\"InR40\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R40\">Dannerbauer et al. 2019</a>; <a name=\"InR118\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R118\">Valentino et al. 2018</a>; <a name=\"InR86\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R86\">Nesvadba et al. 2019</a>). The position of RV4 is marked by the red star, taking into account the magnification from lens modeling. Even after this correction, RV4 is one of the most luminous IR sources of the compilation of SMGs shown in Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#F12\">12</a> (top panel). Its <i>L</i><sub>IR</sub> is comparable to those of the recently published sources of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R10\">B&#233;thermin et al. (2016)</a> (<i>L</i><sub>IR</sub>&#8196;=&#8196;1.1&#8197;&#177;&#8197;0.2&#8197;&#215;&#8197;10<sup>13</sup>&#8198;<i>L</i><sub>&#8857;</sub>) and of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R40\">Dannerbauer et al. (2019)</a> (<i>L</i><sub>IR</sub>&#8196;=&#8196;1.1&#8197;&#177;&#8197;0.1&#8197;&#215;&#8197;10<sup>13</sup>&#8198;<i>L</i><sub>&#8857;</sub>). Although the CO32-A source studied in <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R40\">Dannerbauer et al. (2019)</a> has a [CI](1&#8722;0) to IR luminosity ratio consistent with sources with a less extreme <i>L</i><sub>IR</sub>, RV4 and the source analyzed in <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R10\">B&#233;thermin et al. (2016)</a> exhibit a lower ratio.</p>\n<p><a name=\"F12\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/F12.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19-fig12_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/F12.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 12.</span></a><p><i>Upper panel</i>: [CI] to LIR luminosity ratio (both in <i>L</i><sub>&#8857;</sub>) as a function of infrared luminosity, corrected for lensing magnification when needed, for several samples. The position of RV4 is indicated by the red star. For comparison we show the samples gathered by <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R118\">Valentino et al. (2018)</a> (high-<i>z</i> MS, SMG, and local galaxies), the SPT sample of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R15\">Bothwell et al. (2017)</a>, the SMG sample of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R1\">Alaghband-Zadeh et al. (2013)</a>, the galaxy CO32-A (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R40\">Dannerbauer et al. 2019</a>), SPT-S J213242-5802.9 (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R10\">B&#233;thermin et al. 2016</a>), <i>Planck&#8217;s</i> dusty GEMS (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R86\">Nesvadba et al. 2019</a>), and the local LIRG sample of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R76\">Lu et al. (2017)</a>. <i>Lower panel</i>: [CI] to CO(4&#8722;3) luminosity ratio versus [CI] to IR luminosity ratio (<i>L</i><sub>&#8857;</sub>). The position of RV4 is marked by the red star. This figure is adapted from <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R1\">Alaghband-Zadeh et al. (2013)</a>. Their SMG sample is shown (green triangles) as well as its median position (dark green triangle). The blue squares indicate the quasar sample presented in <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R121\">Walter et al. (2011)</a> with the dark blue square indicating the position of the median of their sample. The SPT sample of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R15\">Bothwell et al. (2017)</a>, <i>Planck&#8217;s</i> dusty GEMS (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R21\">Ca&#241;ameras et al. 2018</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R86\">Nesvadba et al. 2019</a>), and the local sample of LIRGs studied in <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R76\">Lu et al. (2017)</a> are also shown in the figure. The grey lines indicate the contours of the gas density (<i>n</i>) and the radiation field (<i>G</i><sub>0</sub>) for the corresponding <i>L</i><sub>CI</sub>/<i>L</i><sub>CO(4&#8722;3)</sub> and <i>L</i><sub>CI</sub>/<i>L</i><sub>IR</sub> ratios, as produced by the PDR models of <a name=\"InR66\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R66\">Kaufman et al. (1999)</a>.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=12&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201936727\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n</table></div></p>\n<p>The locations of RV4, CO32-A, and the source of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R10\">B&#233;thermin et al. (2016)</a> in the upper panel of Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#F12\">12</a> seems to indicate a possible deviation from the main trend at high IR luminosity, especially if we also consider the <i>z</i>&#8196;&gt; &#8196;2.5 SMG source of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R118\">Valentino et al. (2018)</a> with the lowest <i>L</i><sub>CI</sub>/<i>L</i><sub>IR</sub> ratio. However, more statistics is needed to confirm this. The [CI] luminosity traces the total gas while the IR luminosity traces the SF activity over a typical scale of 100 Myr. Therefore, this ratio can be interpreted as a star formation efficiency indicator. The low <i>L</i><sub>CI</sub>/<i>L</i><sub>IR</sub> ratio is thus an indication that star formation is highly efficient in RV4.</p>\n<p>To explore the properties of the ISM of submillimeter galaxies, <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R1\">Alaghband-Zadeh et al. (2013)</a> investigated the position of galaxies in the <i>L</i><sub>CI</sub>/<i>L</i><sub>CO(4&#8722;3)</sub> versus <i>L</i><sub>CI</sub>/<i>L</i><sub>IR</sub> diagram. Although they acknowledged issues with simple PDR modeling, they compared a sample of quasars and SMGs to a set of PDR models from <a name=\"InR65\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R65\">Kaufman (2009)</a> and found that the SMGs have densities and radiation field strengths that are consistent with those of local starbursts, although &#8764;35% of their SMG sample has lower density and weaker radiation field. They interpret this as an evidence that star formation can be extended in some submillimeter galaxies. The quasar sample is found at higher densities and radiation fields than SMGs on average. In Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#F12\">12</a> (bottom panel), we plot RV4 with the two samples of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R1\">Alaghband-Zadeh et al. (2013)</a> on the <i>L</i><sub>CI</sub>/<i>L</i><sub>CO(4&#8722;3)</sub> versus <i>L</i><sub>CI</sub>/<i>L</i><sub>IR</sub> diagram, along with the SPT data of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R15\">Bothwell et al. (2017)</a>. In terms of <i>L</i><sub>CI</sub>/<i>L</i><sub>CO(4&#8722;3)</sub> ratio, RV4 is consistent with what is found for SMGs, although the ratio is among the 25% highest for the two samples shown in Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#F12\">12</a> (lower panel). The position of RV4 in this diagram is close to the log(<span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19-eq36.gif\"></span> density line, indicating a rather low gas density compared to the other SMGs for the sample. However, in terms of <i>L</i><sub>CI</sub>/<i>L</i><sub>IR</sub>, RV4 has the lowest ratio of the SMG sample, close to the values obtained for quasars. This is an indication of a rather intense radiation field, which is consistent with RV4 being a starburst. This low gas density is also confirmed by the <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19-eq37.gif\"></span> ratio for RV4, which corresponds to only 54 &#177; 11% of the expected value for normal galaxies (<a name=\"InR39\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R39\">Daddi et al. 2015</a>).</p>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S26\"></a>4.4. Size and IR surface brightness</h3>\n<p>In the VLA observations, with a beam size of 0.68&#8243; &#215; 0.55&#8243; and a position angle of 30&#176;, all three blobs are compatible with being point sources. The emission from blob A and B can be deconvolved from the beam but with large uncertainty. Given the sensitivity (2.6 <i>&#956;</i>Jy beam<sup>&#8722;1</sup>) of the VLA observations, measuring an accurate size is challenging and we cannot exclude the possibility that the sources are marginally extended. However, we can measure the sizes of the three RV4 blobs in the <i>uv</i> plane of the NOEMA data, combining all continuum channels. Assuming a circular Gaussian profile, the resulting observed sizes are 0.59&#8243; &#177; 0.05&#8243;, 0.50&#8243; &#177; 0.05&#8243;, and 0.50&#8243; &#177; 0.08&#8243; for blobs A, B, and C, respectively. All sources are clearly resolved and, within the uncertainties, have approximately the same size. We note that these sizes are not corrected for the shear that the strong lensing is causing. We also tried an elliptical Gaussian profile fit, but only the brightest source, blob A, has enough signal to allow for a meaningful fit. For blob A, we obtain an observed major axis of 0.64&#8243; &#177; 0.23&#8243;, an observed minor axis of 0.31&#8243; &#177; 0.6&#8243;, and a position angle of &#8722;75.8 &#177; 14.9&#176;. The observed major axis is elongated approximately E&#8722;W, along the direction where the lens model predicts the greatest shear. The lens model applied in Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#S20\">3.4</a> provided the estimated magnification for each blob along the major and minor axis. Correcting the sizes obtained from CO(5&#8722;4) fits in the <i>uv</i> plane, we obtain a mean delensed size for RV4 of 0.40&#8243; &#177; 0.09 &#215; 0.26&#8243; &#177; 0.06, corresponding to a physical size of 2.64 &#177; 0.58 kpc &#215; 1.71 &#177; 0.38 kpc. RV4 is thus relatively compact.</p>\n<p>Although lensing applies a shear to RV4&#8217;s morphology, the IR surface brightness is conserved. Adopting the lens model that best reproduces the positions of RV4&#8217;s blobs as well as their flux ratios, we distribute the IR luminosity among the three blobs taking into account their respective modeled magnifications. Using the continuum sizes derived from the NOEMA data, we obtain surface brightnesses of &#931;<sub>IR</sub>&#8196;=&#8196;9.5&#8197;&#177;&#8197;2.0&#8197;&#215;&#8197;10<sup>11</sup> <i>L</i><sub>&#8857;</sub> kpc<sup>&#8722;2</sup>, 7.1&#8197;&#177;&#8197;1.5&#8197;&#215;&#8197;10<sup>11</sup> <i>L</i><sub>&#8857;</sub> kpc<sup>&#8722;2</sup>, and 6.5&#8197;&#177;&#8197;1.4&#8197;&#215;&#8197;10<sup>11</sup> <i>L</i><sub>&#8857;</sub> kpc<sup>&#8722;2</sup> for blobsA, B, and C, respectively. These values are consistent within the error bars and provide an average &#931;<sub>IR</sub> of 7.7&#8197;&#177;&#8197;1.6&#8197;&#215;&#8197;10<sup>11</sup> <i>L</i><sub>&#8857;</sub> kpc<sup>&#8722;2</sup> for RV4. In Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#F13\">13</a>, we compare RV4&#8217;s &#931;<sub>IR</sub> to those of other SMGs found in the literature.</p>\n<p><a name=\"F13\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/F13.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19-fig13_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/F13.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 13.</span></a><p>Depletion time as a function of IR surface brightness. The position of RV4 is indicated by the red cross. The depletion time is the one computed from the gas mass estimated from [CI] (Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#S24\">4.2</a>). The blue square is HFLS3 (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R94\">Riechers et al. 2013</a>) at <i>z</i>&#8196;=&#8196;6.34, the green triangle is ALESS73.1 at <i>z</i>&#8196;=&#8196;4.76 (<a name=\"InR43\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R43\">De Breuck et al. 2014</a>), the purple diamond is HDF850.1 (<a name=\"InR85\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R85\">Neri et al. 2014</a>) at <i>z</i>&#8196;=&#8196;5.19, and the pink downward triangle is the source of <a name=\"InR126\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R126\">Yang et al. (2019b)</a> at <i>z</i>&#8196;=&#8196;6.5. The orange dots are the strongly lensed sample of SMG of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R124\">Yang et al. (2017)</a> spanning a redshift range between 2.09 and 4.24. The yellow pentagons are SPT sources from <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R111\">Spilker et al. (2016)</a> and <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R5\">Aravena et al. (2016)</a>. The relation obtained for a sample of MS galaxies at <i>z</i>&#8196;=&#8196;2 by <a name=\"InR53\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R53\">Elbaz et al. (2018)</a> is shown in black solid and dashed lines in the &#931;<sub>IR</sub> range probed by their data.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=13&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201936727\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n</table></div></p>\n<p>RV4 has a notably low depletion time despite a &#931;<sub>IR</sub> only slightly smaller than the sample median. Different assumptions could put RV4 closer to the median along both axis: the system&#8217;s depletion times obtained from dust mass and gas-to-dust ratios are longer than the ones obtained from both [CI] and CO(5&#8722;4). Furthermore, if an obscured AGN is contributing to the <i>L</i><sub>IR</sub> then the depletion time for RV4 would be higher. However, we do not expect these effects could erase all of the current shortfall relative to the <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R53\">Elbaz et al. (2018)</a> MS relation, although the evolution of such relation with redshift is not yet understood. We also note that our method uses the size derived from 3 mm continuum emission which traces the relatively cold dust component (&#8764;520 <i>&#956;</i>m, rest frame) whereas the bulk of the IR emission comes from star-forming regions. Such an offset could have an impact on our derived &#931;<sub>IR</sub> although it is difficult to quantify with the data we have in hand.</p>\n<h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"S27\"></a>5. Interpreting the short depletion time</h2>\n<p>The depletion times estimated through different assumptions ([CI], CO, and dust) yield rather low values 14.4 &#177; 4.7, 17.2 &#177; 2.2, and 32.9.0 &#177; 18.7 Myr, respectively, strongly suggesting that RV4 is experiencing a starburst event. As shown in Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#F12\">12</a>, the <i>L</i><sub>CI</sub>/<i>L</i><sub>IR</sub> ratio is very low compared to a literature sample and seems to indicate a high intensity of the radiation field, close to those measured in quasars.</p>\n<p>In Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#F14\">14</a>, we place RV4 in a Kennicutt-Schmidt diagram (<a name=\"InR68\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R68\">Kennicutt 1998</a>) along with SPT sources from <a name=\"InR13\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R13\">Bothwell et al. (2010)</a> whose properties are close to those of RV4. The &#931;<sub>gas</sub> determined from the CO and [CI] lines places RV4 on the relation of <a name=\"InR37\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R37\">Daddi et al. (2010a)</a> for ULIRGs and SMGs. The &#931;<sub>gas</sub> determined from <i>M</i><sub>dust</sub> is larger but still above the relation of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R37\">Daddi et al. (2010a)</a> for BzK galaxies but right on the universal relation determined by <a name=\"InR16\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R16\">Bouch&#233; et al. (2007)</a>. The position of RV4 in this diagram confirms the starbursting phase suggested by the very short depletion time.</p>\n<p><a name=\"F14\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/F14.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19-fig14_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/F14.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 14.</span></a><p>Star formation rate surface density as a function of gas surface density. The position of RV4 is marker by the red stars. The different colors correspond to the method used to derive the gas mass: light red using the dust mass, red using [CI], and dark red using CO. The grey points are the SPT data from <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R13\">Bothwell et al. (2010)</a> which properties are similar to RV4&#8217;s. The black dotted line is the <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R68\">Kennicutt (1998)</a> relation and the purple dotted line the updated relation from <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R16\">Bouch&#233; et al. (2007)</a>. The blue and light blue dashed lines are the relation of <a name=\"InR38\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R38\">Daddi et al. (2010b)</a> for BzK and SMG galaxies, respectively.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=14&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201936727\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n</table></div></p>\n<p>Even considering a starburst, the typical depletion timescale of a starburst being 100 Myr (for instance, <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R9\">B&#233;thermin et al. 2015</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R5\">Aravena et al. 2016</a>), RV4&#8217;s <i>t</i><sub>depl</sub> is at least a factor 2 lower. A first explanation to this short depletion time could be that RV4 has an unusually high star formation efficiency, defined as the star formation rate divided by the gas mass. However, such high star formation efficiencies are hard to explain theoretically and it has been shown in simulations that major mergers are not that efficient in producing high bursts of star formation in massive gas-rich galaxies (<a name=\"InR54\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R54\">Fensch et al. 2017</a>). A second possibility would be that RV4 encounters a &#8220;recent&#8221; and rapid decrease of the SFR. In this case, the <i>L</i><sub>IR</sub> would trace the SFR over a typical timescale of 100 Myr (<a name=\"InR69\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R69\">Kennicutt &amp; Evans 2012</a>) while the gas mass is probed by emission lines which trace the current gas content. If the SFR and the gas content are both rapidly decreasing, the <i>L</i><sub>IR</sub> would overestimate the instantaneous SFR and thus bias the depletion time toward lower value. Therefore, if the decrease of star formation is very fast the actual depletion time would be closer to typical starburst values.</p>\n<p>If we assume that RV4 lies at least a factor of three above the MS, the stellar mass will be at most 1.7 &#215; 10<sup>11</sup> <i>M</i><sub>&#8857;</sub>. Considering the three estimates of the gas mass derived in Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#S24\">4.2</a>, corrected for magnification, we find gas fractions larger than 16%, 18%, and 30% considering the [CI], CO, and dust based estimates, respectively. These values are not constraining enough for SMGs for which gas fractions are &#8764;50% (e.g. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R38\">Daddi et al. 2010b</a>; <a name=\"InR116\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R116\">Tacconi et al. 2010</a>); therefore we cannot disentangle between the two possible explanations for the short depletion time. Observations of RV4 with the JWST to probe its stellar content will be key to disentangle between the two scenarios.</p>\n<h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"S28\"></a>6. Conclusion</h2>\n<p>We have serendipitously discovered a bright submillimeter galaxy in the field of view of the <i>Herschel</i> imaging of the nearby galaxy IC 3521. The rising SPIRE colors and high flux densities indicate a high-<i>z</i> galaxy with high IR luminosity. We have gathered ancillary data to shed light on the nature of this source and reached the following conclusions.</p>\n<p>The redshift of RV4 is 4.724 as constrained from IRAM/EMIR and NOEMA data. The combination of <i>Herschel</i> and IRAM/NIKA data constrains the IR SED of RV4 resulting in a total IR luminosity of 1.06 &#177; 0.6 &#215; 10<sup>14</sup> <i>L</i><sub>&#8857;</sub>. However, the data in hand do not allow us to exclude the presence of a dust enshrouded AGN that could be contributing to this IR luminosity.</p>\n<p>The <i>Herschel</i> emission splits into three blobs in VLA at 10 cm imaging. The IRAM/NOEMA detection of the CO(5&#8722;4) line of each blob confirms that the three sources are at the same redshift with CO(5&#8722;4) lines having the same width. Combined with the extreme <i>L</i><sub>IR</sub>, we conclude that RV4 is lensed.</p>\n<p>In <i>Spitzer</i>/IRAC and deep CFHT data, two sources acting as a gravitational lens are detected at the center of the virtual arc formed by the three VLA/NOEMA blobs. These two sources, High-<i>z</i> Lens 1 West and East (HL1-W and HL1-E), are located at <i>z</i>&#8196;=&#8196;1.48 by X-shooter data, indicating that they are probably merging. They constitute one of the most distant gravitational lenses found to date in the literature for strong lensing systems. The Einstein radius of the lensing system is 2.2&#8243; &#177; 0.2, as determined from the positions of the three VLA/NOEMA blobs. HL1 is a very peculiar lens with a large Einstein radius combined with a high redshift. We derive a lens model and find that a single halo best reproduces both the positions and the flux ratios of the VLA/NOEMA blobs. This model yields a total magnification of 8.2 &#177; 2.5 and thus an intrinsic <i>L</i><sub>IR</sub> of 1.29 &#215; 10<sup>13</sup> <i>L</i><sub>&#8857;</sub> for RV4. A detailed model of the system will be presented in a companion paper (Ciesla et al., in prep.).</p>\n<p>The SED modeling of HL1-W and HL1-E yields stellar masses of 2.4 &#177; 0.4 and 3.3 &#177; 0.6 &#215; 10<sup>11</sup> <i>M</i><sub>&#8857;</sub>, respectively, and SFR compatible with the two galaxies being passive. The absence of H<i>&#945;</i> emission in HL1-W confirms the low SFR obtained from SED modeling. For HL1-E, a strong H<i>&#945;</i> line is detected together with a strong and broad [NII] line, indicating the possible presence of an AGN. A detailed analysis of the HL1 system will be provided in the companion paper (Ciesla et al., in prep.) as well.</p>\n<p>From the IRAM/EMIR and NOEMA data, we have measured the [CI], CO(4&#8722;3), and CO(5&#8722;4) apparent luminosities. On the one hand RV4 shows a relatively low <i>L</i><sub>[CI]</sub> to <i>L</i><sub>IR</sub> ratio, which can be interpreted as a high star formation efficiency compared to other high-<i>z</i> samples of galaxies, and/or with a hard radiation field. On the other hand, the <i>L</i><sub>[CI]</sub> to <i>L</i><sub>CO(4&#8722;3)</sub> ratio of RV4 is relatively high, indicating a lower gas density. Furthermore, the <i>L</i><sub>CO(5&#8722;4)</sub> to <i>L</i><sub>IR</sub> is only half of the value expected for normal galaxies, indicating a lack of gas.</p>\n<p>We estimate the gas mass of RV4 from different tracers and obtain between 2.7 &#177; 0.7 &#215; 10<sup>11</sup> <i>M</i><sub>&#8857;</sub> and 6.0 &#177; 3.0 &#215; 10<sup>11</sup> <i>M</i><sub>&#8857;</sub>, not corrected for magnification. These numbers yield depletion times between 14.4 &#177; 4.7 and 32.9 &#177; 18.7 Myr. Such short values can be explained by either very high star formation efficiency or by a rapid and recent decrease of star formation. In the former scenario, RV4 would be an intense starburst, difficult to understand from the results of major mergers simulations of gas rich high-<i>z</i> galaxies. In the second scenario, the <i>L</i><sub>IR</sub> probing the star formation activity on a timescale of &#8764;100 Myr and the gas content following the instantaneous SFR, if the star formation activity of RV4 is rapidly decreasing it would bias <i>t</i><sub>depl</sub> toward low values. JWST will definitely be needed to determine the <i>M</i><sub>gas</sub> to <i>M</i><sub>*</sub> ratio of RV4 and investigate the possible low gas content of this SMG.</p>\n<hr width=\"30%\" align=\"left\">\n<div><div>\n<a name=\"FN2\"></a><sup>1</sup> <p class=\"ligne\">The Green Bank Telescope is a facility of the National Science Foundation operated under cooperative agreement by Associated Universities, Inc.</p>\n</div></div>\n<div><div>\n<a name=\"FN3\"></a><sup>2</sup> <p class=\"ligne\">See <a href=\"http://www.iram.fr/IRAMFR/GILDAS\" target=\"_blank\">http://www.iram.fr/IRAMFR/GILDAS</a> for more information about the GILDAS software.</p>\n</div></div>\n<div><div>\n<a name=\"FN4\"></a><sup>3</sup> <p class=\"ligne\">The National Radio Astronomy Observatory is a facility of the National Science Foundation operated under cooperative agreement by Associated Universities, Inc.</p>\n</div></div>\n<div><div>\n<a name=\"FN5\"></a><sup>4</sup> <p class=\"ligne\"><a href=\"https://irsa.ipac.caltech.edu/data/SPITZER/S4G/\" target=\"_blank\">https://irsa.ipac.caltech.edu/data/SPITZER/S4G/</a></p>\n</div></div>\n<div><div>\n<a name=\"FN6\"></a><sup>5</sup> <p class=\"ligne\"><a href=\"https://github.com/cschreib/slinefit\" target=\"_blank\">https://github.com/cschreib/slinefit</a></p>\n</div></div>\n<div><div>\n<a name=\"FN7\"></a><sup>6</sup> <p class=\"ligne\">See <a href=\"https://www.iram.fr/IRAMFR/IS/IS2002/html_2/node131.html\" target=\"_blank\">https://www.iram.fr/IRAMFR/IS/IS2002/html_2/node131.html</a></p>\n</div></div>\n<div><div>\n<a name=\"FN8\"></a><sup>7</sup> <p class=\"ligne\">Publicly available at <a href=\"https://projets.lam.fr/projects/lenstool/wiki/\" target=\"_blank\">https://projets.lam.fr/projects/lenstool/wiki/</a></p>\n</div></div>\n<div><div>\n<a name=\"FN9\"></a><sup>8</sup> <p class=\"ligne\"><a href=\"http://wise2.ipac.caltech.edu/docs/release/allsky/expsup/sec6_3a.html\" target=\"_blank\">http://wise2.ipac.caltech.edu/docs/release/allsky/expsup/sec6_3a.html</a></p>\n</div></div>\n<h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"ack\"></a>Acknowledgments</h2>\n<p>Based on observations carried out under project number P319809 with the IRAM NOEMA Interferometer and project numbers 234-14 and D07-15 with the 30-m telescope. IRAM is supported by INSU/CNRS (France), MPG (Germany) and IGN (Spain). We would like to thank the IRAM staff for their support during the NIKA campaign. MF is supported by a Royal Society &#8211; Science Foundation Ireland University research fellowship. RJA was supported by FONDECYT grant number 1191124. MB acknowledges the FONDECYT regular grant 1170618. AJB acknowledges support from the National Science Foundation via grant AST-0955810. CY acknowledges support from an ESO Fellowship. In both panels, the white contours indicate the positions of the three VLA detections. The positions of the <i>z</i>&#8196;=&#8196;1.48 lens system are indicated by the white arrows.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=5&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201936727\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#F5\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/F6.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19-fig6_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/F6.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 6.</span></a><p><i>Upper panel</i>: VLT/X-shooter 1D spectra of HL1-West. <i>Lower panel</i>: VLT/X-shooter 1D spectra of HL1-East. The inset panels show the probability distribution function for the redshift. The black lines are the best spectral fits obtained with <span class=\"smallcaps\">SLINEFIT</span>.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=6&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201936727\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#F6\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/F7.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19-fig7_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/F7.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 7.</span></a><p>Einstein radii of lenses from the literature as a function of their redshift. The samples from the literature are: SL2S (<a name=\"InR82\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R82\">More et al. 2012</a>), SPT (<a name=\"InR111\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R111\">Spilker et al. 2016</a>), BELLS (<a name=\"InR104\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R104\">Shu et al. 2016</a>), MaNGA (<a name=\"InR117\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R117\">Talbot et al. 2018</a>), H-ATLAS (<a name=\"InR2\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R2\">Amvrosiadis et al. 2018</a>), and the sources of <a name=\"InR72\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R72\">Li et al. (2018)</a> and <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R20\">Ca&#241;ameras et al. (2017)</a>. The position of HL1 is marked by the red star. <i>Upper panel</i>: Einstein radius in arcsecond as a function of the redshift of the lens. Different symbols are from different samples of the literature. <i>Lower panel</i>: same as above, but with the Einstein radius expressed in kiloparsec. The density contours are built from the same sample of literature sources.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=7&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201936727\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#F7\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/F8.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19-fig8_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/F8.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 8.</span></a><p>SED modeling of the two components of HL1 (HL1-W: <i>left panel</i>, HL1-E: <i>right panel</i>). The fit is performed using the filled symbols, circles are photometric points, and diamonds are points obtained averaging the X-shooter spectra over a range of wavelengths. The best fit to the data is shown as a solid line. The subpanels show the difference between the data points and the best-fit models. In each inset panel, we show the position of the component (plain color) in the SFR-<i>M</i><sub>*</sub> diagram along with the MS at <i>z</i>&#8196;=&#8196;1.5 from <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R97\">Schreiber et al. (2015)</a>. The position of the second component is also indicated in light color for comparison. Both components are located below the MS.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=8&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201936727\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#F8\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/F9.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19-fig9_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/F9.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 9.</span></a><p>HL1-W (blue) and HL1-E (green) placed on the BPT diagram. The limit of <a name=\"InR70\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R70\">Kewley et al. (2013)</a> at <i>z</i>&#8196;=&#8196;1.5 is shown in grey.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=9&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201936727\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#F9\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/F10.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19-fig10_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/F10.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 10.</span></a><p>IR SED modeling of RV4. The flux densities are not corrected from magnification. Black circles are the SPIRE data, while diamonds and triangle are the NIKA and VLA fluxes, respectively. The downward triangles indicate the non detection from PACS. The IR SED was fit using the IR libraries of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R99\">Schreiber et al. (2018)</a> (light blue) and <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R48\">Draine et al. (2014)</a> (purple). The MS IR SED derived by <a name=\"InR98\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R98\">Schreiber et al. (2017)</a> from a sample of ALMA detected <i>z</i>&#8196;=&#8196;4 sources is shown with the dashed orange line. A scaling of this MS SED to the 350 <i>&#956;</i>m flux of RV4 leads to a scaling factor of 14.8.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=10&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201936727\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#F10\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/F11.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19-fig11_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/F11.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 11.</span></a><p>Addition of different AGN contributions to the IR SED of RV4. AGN types simulated are type 1 (blue), intermediate type (green), and type 2 (red), as defined in <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R26\">Ciesla et al. (2015)</a>. The different lines correspond to different power of the AGN from 0% (no AGN) to 50% of the total IR luminosity. The gray downward triangles are the WISE 12 and 22 <i>&#956;</i>m upper limits while the black downward triangles are the <i>Herschel</i>/PACS upper limits.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=11&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201936727\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#F11\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/F12.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19-fig12_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/F12.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 12.</span></a><p><i>Upper panel</i>: [CI] to LIR luminosity ratio (both in <i>L</i><sub>&#8857;</sub>) as a function of infrared luminosity, corrected for lensing magnification when needed, for several samples. The position of RV4 is indicated by the red star. For comparison we show the samples gathered by <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R118\">Valentino et al. (2018)</a> (high-<i>z</i> MS, SMG, and local galaxies), the SPT sample of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R15\">Bothwell et al. (2017)</a>, the SMG sample of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R1\">Alaghband-Zadeh et al. (2013)</a>, the galaxy CO32-A (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R40\">Dannerbauer et al. 2019</a>), SPT-S J213242-5802.9 (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R10\">B&#233;thermin et al. 2016</a>), <i>Planck&#8217;s</i> dusty GEMS (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R86\">Nesvadba et al. 2019</a>), and the local LIRG sample of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R76\">Lu et al. (2017)</a>. <i>Lower panel</i>: [CI] to CO(4&#8722;3) luminosity ratio versus [CI] to IR luminosity ratio (<i>L</i><sub>&#8857;</sub>). The position of RV4 is marked by the red star. This figure is adapted from <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R1\">Alaghband-Zadeh et al. (2013)</a>. Their SMG sample is shown (green triangles) as well as its median position (dark green triangle). The blue squares indicate the quasar sample presented in <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R121\">Walter et al. (2011)</a> with the dark blue square indicating the position of the median of their sample. The SPT sample of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R15\">Bothwell et al. (2017)</a>, <i>Planck&#8217;s</i> dusty GEMS (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R21\">Ca&#241;ameras et al. 2018</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R86\">Nesvadba et al. 2019</a>), and the local sample of LIRGs studied in <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R76\">Lu et al. (2017)</a> are also shown in the figure. The grey lines indicate the contours of the gas density (<i>n</i>) and the radiation field (<i>G</i><sub>0</sub>) for the corresponding <i>L</i><sub>CI</sub>/<i>L</i><sub>CO(4&#8722;3)</sub> and <i>L</i><sub>CI</sub>/<i>L</i><sub>IR</sub> ratios, as produced by the PDR models of <a name=\"InR66\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R66\">Kaufman et al. (1999)</a>.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=12&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201936727\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#F12\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/F13.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19-fig13_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/F13.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 13.</span></a><p>Depletion time as a function of IR surface brightness. The position of RV4 is indicated by the red cross. The depletion time is the one computed from the gas mass estimated from [CI] (Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#S24\">4.2</a>). The blue square is HFLS3 (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R94\">Riechers et al. 2013</a>) at <i>z</i>&#8196;=&#8196;6.34, the green triangle is ALESS73.1 at <i>z</i>&#8196;=&#8196;4.76 (<a name=\"InR43\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R43\">De Breuck et al. 2014</a>), the purple diamond is HDF850.1 (<a name=\"InR85\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R85\">Neri et al. 2014</a>) at <i>z</i>&#8196;=&#8196;5.19, and the pink downward triangle is the source of <a name=\"InR126\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R126\">Yang et al. (2019b)</a> at <i>z</i>&#8196;=&#8196;6.5. The orange dots are the strongly lensed sample of SMG of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R124\">Yang et al. (2017)</a> spanning a redshift range between 2.09 and 4.24. The yellow pentagons are SPT sources from <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R111\">Spilker et al. (2016)</a> and <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R5\">Aravena et al. (2016)</a>. The relation obtained for a sample of MS galaxies at <i>z</i>&#8196;=&#8196;2 by <a name=\"InR53\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R53\">Elbaz et al. (2018)</a> is shown in black solid and dashed lines in the &#931;<sub>IR</sub> range probed by their data.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=13&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201936727\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#F13\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n<div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/F14.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19-fig14_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/F14.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 14.</span></a><p>Star formation rate surface density as a function of gas surface density. The position of RV4 is marker by the red stars. The different colors correspond to the method used to derive the gas mass: light red using the dust mass, red using [CI], and dark red using CO. The grey points are the SPT data from <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R13\">Bothwell et al. (2010)</a> which properties are similar to RV4&#8217;s. The black dotted line is the <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R68\">Kennicutt (1998)</a> relation and the purple dotted line the updated relation from <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R16\">Bouch&#233; et al. (2007)</a>. The blue and light blue dashed lines are the relation of <a name=\"InR38\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R38\">Daddi et al. (2010b)</a> for BzK and SMG galaxies, respectively.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=14&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201936727\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\" class=\"in-txt\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#F14\">In the text</a></td></tr>\n</table></div>\n</div>\n\n\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n    <div id=\"metrics-tabs\" data-doi=\"10.1051/0004-6361/201936727\" data-edps_ref=\"aa36727-19\">\n<nav class=\"toolbar\">\n\t<button class=\"toolbar-item\" id=\"metrics-siq\">Current usage metrics</button>\n\t<button class=\"toolbar-item\" id=\"info\">About article metrics</button>\n    \n\t\n\t<button class=\"toolbar-item\" id=\"return\">Return to article</button>\n</nav>\n\n<div class=\"panel\" data-for=\"metrics-siq\">\n</div>\n\n<div class=\"panel\" data-for=\"metrics-alm\"></div>\n\n<div class=\"panel\" data-for=\"info\">\n\t\n\n\t<p>Current usage metrics show cumulative count of Article Views (full-text article views including HTML views, PDF and ePub downloads, according to the available data)  and Abstracts Views on Vision4Press platform.</p>\n\n\t<p>Data correspond to usage on the plateform after 2015. The current usage metrics is available 48-96 hours after online publication and is updated daily on week days.</p>\n\n\t<div class=\"msg msg-info\">\n\t\t<span class=\"ico Ilbert\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_author_institution\" content=\"Aix Marseille Univ., CNRS, CNES, LAM, Marseille, France\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_title\" content=\"A hyper luminous starburst at z = 4.72 magnified by a lensing galaxy pair at z = 1.48\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_online_date\" content=\"2020/03/02\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_publication_date\" content=\"2020/03/01\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_volume\" content=\"635\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_firstpage\" content=\"A27\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_doi\" content=\"10.1051/0004-6361/201936727\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_bibcode\" content=\"2020A%26A...635A..27C\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_abstract_html_url\" content=\"https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/abs/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_fulltext_html_url\" content=\"https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_pdf_url\" content=\"https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/pdf/2020/03/aa36727-19.pdf\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_issn\" content=\"0004-6361\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_issn\" content=\"1432-0746\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_language\" content=\"en\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"galaxies: high-redshift\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"galaxies: ISM\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"galaxies: starburst\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"galaxies: star formation\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"submillimeter: galaxies\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_article_type\" content=\"Research Article\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_abstract\" lang=\"en\" content=\"We serendipitously discovered in the &lt;i&gt;Herschel&lt;i/&gt; Reference Survey an extremely bright infrared source with &lt;i&gt;S&lt;i/&gt;&lt;sub&gt;500&lt;sub/&gt;\u2004\u223c\u2004120 mJy in the line of sight of the Virgo cluster which we name Red Virgo 4 (RV4). Based on IRAM/EMIR and IRAM/NOEMA detections of the CO(5\u22124), CO(4\u22123), and [CI] lines, RV4 is located at a redshift of 4.724, yielding a total observed infrared luminosity of 1.1 \u00b1 0.6 \u00d7 10&lt;sup&gt;14&lt;sup/&gt; &lt;i&gt;L&lt;i/&gt;&lt;sub&gt;\u2299&lt;sub/&gt;. At the position of the &lt;i&gt;Herschel&lt;i/&gt; emission, three blobs are detected with the VLA at 10 cm. The CO(5\u22124) line detection of each blob confirms that they are at the same redshift with the same line width, indicating that they are multiple images of the same source. In &lt;i&gt;Spitzer&lt;i/&gt; and deep optical observations, two sources, High-&lt;i&gt;z&lt;i/&gt; Lens 1 (HL1) West and HL1 East, are detected at the center of the three VLA/NOEMA blobs. These two sources are placed at &lt;i&gt;z&lt;i/&gt;\u2004=\u20041.48 with X-shooter spectra, suggesting that they could be merging and gravitationally lensing the emission of RV4. HL1 is the second most distant lens known to date in strong lensing systems. Constrained by the position of the three VLA/NOEMA blobs, the Einstein radius of the lensing system is 2.2\u2033 \u00b1 0.2 (20 kpc). The high redshift of HL1 and the large Einstein radius are highly unusual for a strong lensing system. In this paper, we present the insterstellar medium properties of the background source RV4. Different estimates of the gas depletion time yield low values suggesting that RV4 is a starburst galaxy. Among all high-&lt;i&gt;z&lt;i/&gt; submillimeter galaxies, this source exhibits one of the lowest &lt;i&gt;L&lt;i/&gt;&lt;sub&gt;[CI]&lt;sub/&gt; to &lt;i&gt;L&lt;i/&gt;&lt;sub&gt;IR&lt;sub/&gt; ratios, 3.2 \u00b1 0.9 \u00d7 10&lt;sup&gt;\u22126&lt;sup/&gt;, suggesting an extremely short gas depletion time of only 14 \u00b1 5 Myr. It also shows a relatively high &lt;i&gt;L&lt;i/&gt;&lt;sub&gt;[CI]&lt;sub/&gt; to &lt;i&gt;L&lt;i/&gt;&lt;sub&gt;CO(4\u22123)&lt;sub/&gt; ratio (0.7 \u00b1 0.2) and low &lt;i&gt;L&lt;i/&gt;&lt;sub&gt;CO(5\u22124)&lt;sub/&gt; to &lt;i&gt;L&lt;i/&gt;&lt;sub&gt;IR&lt;sub/&gt; ratio (only \u223c50% of the value expected for normal galaxies) hinting at low density of gas. Finally, we discuss the short depletion time of RV4. It can be explained by either a very high star formation efficiency, which is difficult to reconcile with major mergers simulations of high-&lt;i&gt;z&lt;i/&gt; galaxies, or a rapid decrease of star formation, which would bias the estimate of the depletion time toward an artificially low value.\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_reference\" content=\"citation_author=S. function (request, callback) {\n\t        var term = request.term;\n            $.ajax({\n                url: '/index.php',\n                dataType: 'json',\n                method: 'GET',\n                data: {\n                    option: 'com_solr',\n                    task: 'auto_complete',\n                    query: term\n                },\n                success: function (data) {\n                    var suggestions = [];\n                    try {\n                        data.suggest.default[term].suggestions.forEach(function (s) { suggestions.push(s.term)}) } catch (e) {\n                    }\n\n                    callback(suggestions);\n                },\n                error: function (err) {\n                    callback([]);\n                }\n            });\n        };\n\n\t\t$('#search').find('input[name=q]').autocomplete({\n\t\t\tsource: source\n\t\t});\n\t});\n</script>\n\n                          <div class=\"header-cover\">\n                <div class=\"panel\" data-for=\"metrics-siq\">\n</div>\n\n<div class=\"panel\" data-for=\"metrics-alm\"></div>\n\n<div class=\"panel\" data-for=\"info\">\n\t\n\n\t<p>Current usage metrics show cumulative count of Article Views (full-text article views including HTML views, PDF and ePub downloads, according to the available data)  and Abstracts Views on Vision4Press platform.</p>\n\n\t<p>Data correspond to usage on the plateform after 2015. The current usage metrics is available 48-96 hours after online publication and is updated daily on week days.</p>\n\n\t<div class=\"msg msg-info\">\n\t\t<span class=\"ico Ilbert\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_author_institution\" content=\"Aix Marseille Univ., CNRS, CNES, LAM, Marseille, France\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_title\" content=\"A hyper luminous starburst at z = 4.72 magnified by a lensing galaxy pair at z = 1.48\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_online_date\" content=\"2020/03/02\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_publication_date\" content=\"2020/03/01\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_volume\" content=\"635\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_firstpage\" content=\"A27\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_doi\" content=\"10.1051/0004-6361/201936727\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_bibcode\" content=\"2020A%26A...635A..27C\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_abstract_html_url\" content=\"https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/abs/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_fulltext_html_url\" content=\"https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_pdf_url\" content=\"https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/pdf/2020/03/aa36727-19.pdf\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_issn\" content=\"0004-6361\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_issn\" content=\"1432-0746\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_language\" content=\"en\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"galaxies: high-redshift\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"galaxies: ISM\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"galaxies: starburst\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"galaxies: star formation\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"submillimeter: galaxies\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_article_type\" content=\"Research Article\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_abstract\" lang=\"en\" content=\"We serendipitously discovered in the &lt;i&gt;Herschel&lt;i/&gt; Reference Survey an extremely bright infrared source with &lt;i&gt;S&lt;i/&gt;&lt;sub&gt;500&lt;sub/&gt;\u2004\u223c\u2004120 mJy in the line of sight of the Virgo cluster which we name Red Virgo 4 (RV4). Based on IRAM/EMIR and IRAM/NOEMA detections of the CO(5\u22124), CO(4\u22123), and [CI] lines, RV4 is located at a redshift of 4.724, yielding a total observed infrared luminosity of 1.1 \u00b1 0.6 \u00d7 10&lt;sup&gt;14&lt;sup/&gt; &lt;i&gt;L&lt;i/&gt;&lt;sub&gt;\u2299&lt;sub/&gt;. At the position of the &lt;i&gt;Herschel&lt;i/&gt; emission, three blobs are detected with the VLA at 10 cm. The CO(5\u22124) line detection of each blob confirms that they are at the same redshift with the same line width, indicating that they are multiple images of the same source. In &lt;i&gt;Spitzer&lt;i/&gt; and deep optical observations, two sources, High-&lt;i&gt;z&lt;i/&gt; Lens 1 (HL1) West and HL1 East, are detected at the center of the three VLA/NOEMA blobs. These two sources are placed at &lt;i&gt;z&lt;i/&gt;\u2004=\u20041.48 with X-shooter spectra, suggesting that they could be merging and gravitationally lensing the emission of RV4. HL1 is the second most distant lens known to date in strong lensing systems. Constrained by the position of the three VLA/NOEMA blobs, the Einstein radius of the lensing system is 2.2\u2033 \u00b1 0.2 (20 kpc). The high redshift of HL1 and the large Einstein radius are highly unusual for a strong lensing system. In this paper, we present the insterstellar medium properties of the background source RV4. Different estimates of the gas depletion time yield low values suggesting that RV4 is a starburst galaxy. Among all high-&lt;i&gt;z&lt;i/&gt; submillimeter galaxies, this source exhibits one of the lowest &lt;i&gt;L&lt;i/&gt;&lt;sub&gt;[CI]&lt;sub/&gt; to &lt;i&gt;L&lt;i/&gt;&lt;sub&gt;IR&lt;sub/&gt; ratios, 3.2 \u00b1 0.9 \u00d7 10&lt;sup&gt;\u22126&lt;sup/&gt;, suggesting an extremely short gas depletion time of only 14 \u00b1 5 Myr. It also shows a relatively high &lt;i&gt;L&lt;i/&gt;&lt;sub&gt;[CI]&lt;sub/&gt; to &lt;i&gt;L&lt;i/&gt;&lt;sub&gt;CO(4\u22123)&lt;sub/&gt; ratio (0.7 \u00b1 0.2) and low &lt;i&gt;L&lt;i/&gt;&lt;sub&gt;CO(5\u22124)&lt;sub/&gt; to &lt;i&gt;L&lt;i/&gt;&lt;sub&gt;IR&lt;sub/&gt; ratio (only \u223c50% of the value expected for normal galaxies) hinting at low density of gas. Finally, we discuss the short depletion time of RV4. It can be explained by either a very high star formation efficiency, which is difficult to reconcile with major mergers simulations of high-&lt;i&gt;z&lt;i/&gt; galaxies, or a rapid decrease of star formation, which would bias the estimate of the depletion time toward an artificially low value.\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_reference\" content=\"citation_author=S. function (request, callback) {\n\t        var term = request.term;\n            $.ajax({\n                url: '/index.php',\n                dataType: 'json',\n                method: 'GET',\n                data: {\n                    option: 'com_solr',\n                    task: 'auto_complete',\n                    query: term\n                },\n                success: function (data) {\n                    var suggestions = [];\n                    try {\n                        data.suggest.default[term].suggestions.forEach(function (s) { suggestions.push(s.term)}) } catch (e) {\n                    }\n\n                    callback(suggestions);\n                },\n                error: function (err) {\n                    callback([]);\n                }\n            });\n        };\n\n\t\t$('#search').find('input[name=q]').autocomplete({\n\t\t\tsource: source\n\t\t});\n\t});\n</script>\n\n                          <div class=\"header-cover\">\n                <div class=\"wrap\">                                  </div>                  \n              </div>\n                    </header>\n\n        <main class=\"aa\" id=\"main\">\n\n            <!--div Abstracts Views on Vision4Press platform.</p>\n\n\t<p>Data correspond to usage on the plateform after 2015. The current usage metrics is available 48-96 hours after online publication and is updated daily on week days.</p>\n\n\t<div class=\"msg msg-info\">\n\t\t<span class=\"ico Saanich Road, Victoria, BC V9E 2E7, Canada\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_author\" content=\"B. Ferrarese\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_author_institution\" content=\"National Research Council, 5071 W. Saanich Road, Victoria, BC V9E 2E7, Canada\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_author\" content=\"R. Gobat\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_author_institution\" content=\"Instituto de F\u00edsica, Pontificia Universidad Cat\u00f3lica de Valpara\u00edso, Casilla 4059, Valpara\u00edso, Chile\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_author\" content=\"O. Ilbert\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_author_institution\" content=\"Aix Marseille Univ., CNRS, CNES, LAM, Marseille, France\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_title\" content=\"A hyper luminous starburst at z = 4.72 magnified by a lensing galaxy pair at z = 1.48\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_online_date\" content=\"2020/03/02\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_publication_date\" content=\"2020/03/01\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_volume\" content=\"635\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_firstpage\" content=\"A27\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_doi\" content=\"10.1051/0004-6361/201936727\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_bibcode\" content=\"2020A%26A...635A..27C\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_abstract_html_url\" content=\"https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/abs/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_fulltext_html_url\" content=\"https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_pdf_url\" content=\"https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/pdf/2020/03/aa36727-19.pdf\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_issn\" content=\"0004-6361\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_issn\" content=\"1432-0746\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_language\" content=\"en\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"galaxies: high-redshift\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"galaxies: ISM\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"galaxies: starburst\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"galaxies: star formation\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"submillimeter: galaxies\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_article_type\" content=\"Research Article\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_abstract\" lang=\"en\" content=\"We serendipitously discovered in the &lt;i&gt;Herschel&lt;i/&gt; Reference Survey an extremely bright infrared source with &lt;i&gt;S&lt;i/&gt;&lt;sub&gt;500&lt;sub/&gt;\u2004\u223c\u2004120 mJy in the line of sight of the Virgo cluster which we name Red Virgo 4 (RV4). Based on IRAM/EMIR and IRAM/NOEMA detections of the CO(5\u22124), CO(4\u22123), and [CI] lines, RV4 is located at a redshift of 4.724, yielding a total observed infrared luminosity of 1.1 \u00b1 0.6 \u00d7 10&lt;sup&gt;14&lt;sup/&gt; &lt;i&gt;L&lt;i/&gt;&lt;sub&gt;\u2299&lt;sub/&gt;. At the position of the &lt;i&gt;Herschel&lt;i/&gt; emission, three blobs are detected with the VLA at 10 cm. The CO(5\u22124) line detection of each blob confirms that they are at the same redshift with the same line width, indicating that they are multiple images of the same source. In &lt;i&gt;Spitzer&lt;i/&gt; and deep optical observations, two sources, High-&lt;i&gt;z&lt;i/&gt; Lens 1 (HL1) West and HL1 East, are detected at the center of the three VLA/NOEMA blobs. These two sources are placed at &lt;i&gt;z&lt;i/&gt;\u2004=\u20041.48 with X-shooter spectra, suggesting that they could be merging and gravitationally lensing the emission of RV4. HL1 is the second most distant lens known to date in strong lensing systems. Constrained by the position of the three VLA/NOEMA blobs, the Einstein radius of the lensing system is 2.2\u2033 \u00b1 0.2 (20 kpc). The high redshift of HL1 and the large Einstein radius are highly unusual for a strong lensing system. In this paper, we present the insterstellar medium properties of the background source RV4. Different estimates of the gas depletion time yield low values suggesting that RV4 is a starburst galaxy. Among all high-&lt;i&gt;z&lt;i/&gt; submillimeter galaxies, this source exhibits one of the lowest &lt;i&gt;L&lt;i/&gt;&lt;sub&gt;[CI]&lt;sub/&gt; to &lt;i&gt;L&lt;i/&gt;&lt;sub&gt;IR&lt;sub/&gt; ratios, 3.2 \u00b1 0.9 \u00d7 10&lt;sup&gt;\u22126&lt;sup/&gt;, suggesting an extremely short gas depletion time of only 14 \u00b1 5 Myr. It also shows a relatively high &lt;i&gt;L&lt;i/&gt;&lt;sub&gt;[CI]&lt;sub/&gt; to &lt;i&gt;L&lt;i/&gt;&lt;sub&gt;CO(4\u22123)&lt;sub/&gt; ratio (0.7 \u00b1 0.2) and low &lt;i&gt;L&lt;i/&gt;&lt;sub&gt;CO(5\u22124)&lt;sub/&gt; to &lt;i&gt;L&lt;i/&gt;&lt;sub&gt;IR&lt;sub/&gt; ratio (only \u223c50% of the value expected for normal galaxies) hinting at low density of gas. Finally, we discuss the short depletion time of RV4. It can be explained by either a very high star formation efficiency, which is difficult to reconcile with major mergers simulations of high-&lt;i&gt;z&lt;i/&gt; galaxies, or a rapid decrease of star formation, which would bias the estimate of the depletion time toward an artificially low value.\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_reference\" content=\"citation_author=S. Alaghband-Zadeh;citation_author=S. C. Chapman;citation_author=A. M. function (request, callback) {\n\t        var term = request.term;\n            $.ajax({\n                url: '/index.php',\n                dataType: 'json',\n                method: 'GET',\n                data: {\n                    option: 'com_solr',\n                    task: 'auto_complete',\n                    query: term\n                },\n                success: function (data) {\n                    var suggestions = [];\n                    try {\n                        data.suggest.default[term].suggestions.forEach(function (s) { suggestions.push(s.term)}) } catch (e) {\n                    }\n\n                    callback(suggestions);\n                },\n                error: function (err) {\n                    callback([]);\n                }\n            });\n        };\n\n\t\t$('#search').find('input[name=q]').autocomplete({\n\t\t\tsource: source\n\t\t});\n\t});\n</script>\n\n                          <div class=\"header-cover\">\n                <div id=\"article\">\r\n    <?xml version=\"1.0\" encoding=\"ASCII\" standalone=\"yes\"?>\n<!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC \"-//W3C//DTD XHTML 1.0 Transitional//EN\" \"\">\n\n    <div id=\"annex\">\n      <h2 class=\"sec\">Table 3. </h2>\n      <p>Lensing modeling parameters.</p>\n      <div class=\"tab\">\n        <table width=\"100%\" class=\"fm\" frame=\"hsides\" rules=\"groups\">\n<thead>\n<tr>\n<th align=\"left\">Model</th>\n<th align=\"center\">&#916;<i>&#945;</i><sup><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/T3.html#TFN1\">(a)</a></sup></th>\n<th align=\"center\">&#916;<i>&#948;</i><sup><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/T3.html#TFN1\">(a)</a></sup></th>\n<th align=\"center\"><i>e</i><sup><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/T3.html#TFN4\">(d)</a></sup></th>\n<th align=\"center\"><i>r</i><sub>cut</sub><sup><a s<sup>&#8722;1</sup>)</th>\n</tr>\n</thead>\n<tbody>\n<tr>\n<td align=\"left\">DM1</td>\n<td align=\"center\"><span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19-eq6.gif\" width=\"48\" height=\"20\" /></span></td>\n<td align=\"center\"><span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19-eq11.gif\" width=\"48\" height=\"20\" /></span></td>\n</tr>\n</tbody>\n</table>\n      </div>\n      <div class=\"history\">\n<p><b>Notes.</b></p>\n<div><a name=\"TFN1\" id=\"TFN1\"></a><sup>(a)</sup> <p class=\"ligne\">Center position from an arbitrary reference taken at RA:188.68699 and Dec:+7.1356514.</p></div>\n<div><a name=\"TFN2\" id=\"TFN2\"></a><sup>(b)</sup> <p class=\"ligne\">Potential ellipticity, defined as (<i>a</i><sup>2</sup>&#8197;&#8722;&#8197;<i>b</i><sup>2</sup>)/(<i>a</i><sup>2</sup>&#8197;+&#8197;<i>b</i><sup>2</sup>).</p></div>\n<div><a name=\"TFN3\" id=\"TFN3\"></a><sup>(c)</sup> <p class=\"ligne\">Potential angle.</p></div>\n<div><a name=\"TFN4\" id=\"TFN4\"></a><sup>(d)</sup> <p class=\"ligne\">Core radius of the dPIE potential.</p></div>\n<div><a name=\"TFN5\" id=\"TFN5\"></a><sup>(e)</sup> <p class=\"ligne\">Cut radius, fixed to 500 kpc as it is not constrained from our data.</p></div>\n<div><a name=\"TFN6\" id=\"TFN6\"></a><sup>(f)</sup> <p class=\"ligne\">Velocity dispersion.</p></div>\n</div>\n    </div>\n  \n\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n    <div id=\"metrics-tabs\" data-doi=\"10.1051/0004-6361/201936727\" data-edps_ref=\"aa36727-19\">\n<nav
