Ilbert\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_author_institution\" content=\"Aix Marseille Univ., CNRS, CNES, LAM, Marseille, France\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_title\" content=\"A hyper luminous starburst at z = 4.72 magnified by a lensing galaxy pair at z = 1.48\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_online_date\" content=\"2020/03/02\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_publication_date\" content=\"2020/03/01\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_volume\" content=\"635\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_firstpage\" content=\"A27\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_doi\" content=\"10.1051/0004-6361/201936727\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_bibcode\" content=\"2020A%26A...635A..27C\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_abstract_html_url\" content=\"https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/abs/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_fulltext_html_url\" content=\"https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_pdf_url\" content=\"https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/pdf/2020/03/aa36727-19.pdf\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_issn\" content=\"0004-6361\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_issn\" content=\"1432-0746\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_language\" content=\"en\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"galaxies: high-redshift\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"galaxies: ISM\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"galaxies: starburst\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"galaxies: star formation\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"submillimeter: galaxies\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_article_type\" content=\"Research Article\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_abstract\" lang=\"en\" content=\"We serendipitously discovered in the &lt;i&gt;Herschel&lt;i/&gt; Reference Survey an extremely bright infrared source with &lt;i&gt;S&lt;i/&gt;&lt;sub&gt;500&lt;sub/&gt;\u2004\u223c\u2004120 mJy in the line of sight of the Virgo cluster which we name Red Virgo 4 (RV4). Based on IRAM/EMIR and IRAM/NOEMA detections of the CO(5\u22124), CO(4\u22123), and [CI] lines, RV4 is located at a redshift of 4.724, yielding a total observed infrared luminosity of 1.1 \u00b1 0.6 \u00d7 10&lt;sup&gt;14&lt;sup/&gt; &lt;i&gt;L&lt;i/&gt;&lt;sub&gt;\u2299&lt;sub/&gt;. At the position of the &lt;i&gt;Herschel&lt;i/&gt; emission, three blobs are detected with the VLA at 10 cm. The CO(5\u22124) line detection of each blob confirms that they are at the same redshift with the same line width, indicating that they are multiple images of the same source. In &lt;i&gt;Spitzer&lt;i/&gt; and deep optical observations, two sources, High-&lt;i&gt;z&lt;i/&gt; Lens 1 (HL1) West and HL1 East, are detected at the center of the three VLA/NOEMA blobs. These two sources are placed at &lt;i&gt;z&lt;i/&gt;\u2004=\u20041.48 with X-shooter spectra, suggesting that they could be merging and gravitationally lensing the emission of RV4. HL1 is the second most distant lens known to date in strong lensing systems. Constrained by the position of the three VLA/NOEMA blobs, the Einstein radius of the lensing system is 2.2\u2033 \u00b1 0.2 (20 kpc). The high redshift of HL1 and the large Einstein radius are highly unusual for a strong lensing system. In this paper, we present the insterstellar medium properties of the background source RV4. Different estimates of the gas depletion time yield low values suggesting that RV4 is a starburst galaxy. Among all high-&lt;i&gt;z&lt;i/&gt; submillimeter galaxies, this source exhibits one of the lowest &lt;i&gt;L&lt;i/&gt;&lt;sub&gt;[CI]&lt;sub/&gt; to &lt;i&gt;L&lt;i/&gt;&lt;sub&gt;IR&lt;sub/&gt; ratios, 3.2 \u00b1 0.9 \u00d7 10&lt;sup&gt;\u22126&lt;sup/&gt;, suggesting an extremely short gas depletion time of only 14 \u00b1 5 Myr. It also shows a relatively high &lt;i&gt;L&lt;i/&gt;&lt;sub&gt;[CI]&lt;sub/&gt; to &lt;i&gt;L&lt;i/&gt;&lt;sub&gt;CO(4\u22123)&lt;sub/&gt; ratio (0.7 \u00b1 0.2) and low &lt;i&gt;L&lt;i/&gt;&lt;sub&gt;CO(5\u22124)&lt;sub/&gt; to &lt;i&gt;L&lt;i/&gt;&lt;sub&gt;IR&lt;sub/&gt; ratio (only \u223c50% of the value expected for normal galaxies) hinting at low density of gas. Finally, we discuss the short depletion time of RV4. It can be explained by either a very high star formation efficiency, which is difficult to reconcile with major mergers simulations of high-&lt;i&gt;z&lt;i/&gt; galaxies, or a rapid decrease of star formation, which would bias the estimate of the depletion time toward an artificially low value.\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_reference\" content=\"citation_author=S. Alaghband-Zadeh;citation_author=S. C. Chapman;citation_author=A. M. Swinbank;citation_publication_date=2013;citation_journal_title=MNRAS;citation_volume=435;citation_firstpage=1493;\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_reference\" content=\"citation_author=A. Amvrosiadis;citation_author=S. A. Eales;citation_author=M. Negrello;citation_publication_date=2018;citation_journal_title=MNRAS;citation_volume=475;citation_firstpage=4939;\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_reference\" content=\"citation_author=G. Aniano;citation_author=B. T. Draine;citation_author=D. Apostolovski;citation_author=M. Aravena;citation_author=T. Anguita;citation_publication_date=2019;citation_journal_title=A&amp;A;citation_volume=628;citation_firstpage=A23;\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_reference\" content=\"citation_author=M. Aravena;citation_author=J. S. Spilker;citation_author=M. Bethermin;citation_publication_date=2016;citation_journal_title=MNRAS;citation_volume=457;citation_firstpage=4406;\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_reference\" content=\"citation_author=A. J. function (request, callback) {\n\t        var term = request.term;\n            $.ajax({\n                url: '/index.php',\n                dataType: 'json',\n                method: 'GET',\n                data: {\n                    option: 'com_solr',\n                    task: 'auto_complete',\n                    query: term\n                },\n                success: function (data) {\n                    var suggestions = [];\n                    try {\n                        data.suggest.default[term].suggestions.forEach(function (s) { suggestions.push(s.term)}) } catch (e) {\n                    }\n\n                    callback(suggestions);\n                },\n                error: function (err) {\n                    callback([]);\n                }\n            });\n Ilbert\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_author_institution\" content=\"Aix Marseille Univ., CNRS, CNES, LAM, Marseille, France\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_title\" content=\"A hyper luminous starburst at z = 4.72 magnified by a lensing galaxy pair at z = 1.48\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_online_date\" content=\"2020/03/02\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_publication_date\" content=\"2020/03/01\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_volume\" content=\"635\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_firstpage\" content=\"A27\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_doi\" content=\"10.1051/0004-6361/201936727\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_bibcode\" content=\"2020A%26A...635A..27C\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_abstract_html_url\" content=\"https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/abs/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_fulltext_html_url\" content=\"https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_pdf_url\" content=\"https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/pdf/2020/03/aa36727-19.pdf\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_issn\" content=\"0004-6361\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_issn\" content=\"1432-0746\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_language\" content=\"en\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"galaxies: high-redshift\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"galaxies: ISM\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"galaxies: starburst\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"galaxies: star formation\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"submillimeter: galaxies\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_article_type\" content=\"Research Article\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_abstract\" lang=\"en\" content=\"We serendipitously discovered in the &lt;i&gt;Herschel&lt;i/&gt; Reference Survey an extremely bright infrared source with &lt;i&gt;S&lt;i/&gt;&lt;sub&gt;500&lt;sub/&gt;\u2004\u223c\u2004120 mJy in the line of sight of the Virgo cluster which we name Red Virgo 4 (RV4). Based on IRAM/EMIR and IRAM/NOEMA detections of the CO(5\u22124), CO(4\u22123), and [CI] lines, RV4 is located at a redshift of 4.724, yielding a total observed infrared luminosity of 1.1 \u00b1 0.6 \u00d7 10&lt;sup&gt;14&lt;sup/&gt; &lt;i&gt;L&lt;i/&gt;&lt;sub&gt;\u2299&lt;sub/&gt;. At the position of the &lt;i&gt;Herschel&lt;i/&gt; emission, three blobs are detected with the VLA at 10 cm. The CO(5\u22124) line detection of each blob confirms that they are at the same redshift with the same line width, indicating that they are multiple images of the same source. In &lt;i&gt;Spitzer&lt;i/&gt; and deep optical observations, two sources, High-&lt;i&gt;z&lt;i/&gt; Lens 1 (HL1) West and HL1 East, are detected at the center of the three VLA/NOEMA blobs. These two sources are placed at &lt;i&gt;z&lt;i/&gt;\u2004=\u20041.48 with X-shooter spectra, suggesting that they could be merging and gravitationally lensing the emission of RV4. HL1 is the second most distant lens known to date in strong lensing systems. Constrained by the position of the three VLA/NOEMA blobs, the Einstein radius of the lensing system is 2.2\u2033 \u00b1 0.2 (20 kpc). The high redshift of HL1 and the large Einstein radius are highly unusual for a strong lensing system. In this paper, we present the insterstellar medium properties of the background source RV4. Different estimates of the gas depletion time yield low values suggesting that RV4 is a starburst galaxy. Among all high-&lt;i&gt;z&lt;i/&gt; submillimeter galaxies, this source exhibits one of the lowest &lt;i&gt;L&lt;i/&gt;&lt;sub&gt;[CI]&lt;sub/&gt; to &lt;i&gt;L&lt;i/&gt;&lt;sub&gt;IR&lt;sub/&gt; ratios, 3.2 \u00b1 0.9 \u00d7 10&lt;sup&gt;\u22126&lt;sup/&gt;, suggesting an extremely short gas depletion time of only 14 \u00b1 5 Myr. It also shows a relatively high &lt;i&gt;L&lt;i/&gt;&lt;sub&gt;[CI]&lt;sub/&gt; to &lt;i&gt;L&lt;i/&gt;&lt;sub&gt;CO(4\u22123)&lt;sub/&gt; ratio (0.7 \u00b1 0.2) and low &lt;i&gt;L&lt;i/&gt;&lt;sub&gt;CO(5\u22124)&lt;sub/&gt; to &lt;i&gt;L&lt;i/&gt;&lt;sub&gt;IR&lt;sub/&gt; ratio (only \u223c50% of the value expected for normal galaxies) hinting at low density of gas. Finally, we discuss the short depletion time of RV4. It can be explained by either a very high star formation efficiency, which is difficult to reconcile with major mergers simulations of high-&lt;i&gt;z&lt;i/&gt; galaxies, or a rapid decrease of star formation, which would bias the estimate of the depletion time toward an artificially low value.\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_reference\" content=\"citation_author=S. Alaghband-Zadeh;citation_author=S. C. Chapman;citation_author=A. M. Swinbank;citation_publication_date=2013;citation_journal_title=MNRAS;citation_volume=435;citation_firstpage=1493;\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_reference\" content=\"citation_author=A. Negrello;citation_publication_date=2018;citation_journal_title=MNRAS;citation_volume=475;citation_firstpage=4939;\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_reference\" content=\"citation_author=G.         data: {\n                    option: 'com_solr',\n                    task: 'auto_complete',\n                    query: term\n                },\n                success: function (data) {\n                    var suggestions = [];\n                    try {\n                        data.suggest.default[term].suggestions.forEach(function (s) { suggestions.push(s.term)}) } catch (e) {\n                    }\n\n                    callback(suggestions);\n                },\n                error: function (err) {\n                    callback([]);\n                }\n            });\n class=\"summary full\" >\n\t<table>\n\t\t\n\t\n\t\t<tr>\n\t\t<th valign=\"top\">\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\tIssue\n\t\t\t\t\t</th>\n\t\t<td 2020\t\t\t\t</div>\n\t\t\t\t\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t</td>\n\t<tr><td colspan=\"3\" ></td></tr>\n\t<tr><td colspan=\"3\" class=\"sep_issue\"></td></tr>\n\t</tr>\n\t\n\t\t\t\t\t\t<tr>\n\t\t\t\t<th>\n\t\t\t\t\tArticle Number\n\t\t\t\t\t</th>\n\t\t\t\t<td></td>\n\t\t\t\t<td>A27</td>\n\t\t\t</tr>\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<tr>\n\t\t\t\t<th>\n\t\t\t\t\tNumber of page(s)\n\t\t\t\t\t</th>\n\t\t\t\t<td></td>\n\t\t\t\t<td>14</td>\n\t\t\t</tr>\n\t\t\t\t\n\t\t\t<tr>\n\t\t\t<th>Section</th>\n\t\t\t<td></td>\n\t\t\t<td>Extragalactic astronomy</td>\n\t\t</tr>\n\t\t\n\t\t\t<tr>\n\t\t\t<th>DOI</th>\n\t\t\t<td></td>\n\t\t\t<td>\n\t\t\t\t<a href=\"https://doi.org/10.1051/0004-6361/201936727\">\n\t\t\t\t\thttps://doi.org/10.1051/0004-6361/201936727\n\t\t\t\t</a>\n\t\t\t</td>\n\t\t</tr>\n\t\t\n\t\t\t<tr>\n\t\t\t<th>Published online</th>\n\t\t\t<td></td>\n\t\t\t<td>\n\t\t\t\t02 March 2020\n\t\t\t</td>\n\t\t</tr>\n\t\t\n\t\t</table>\n</div>\n\r\n\r\n\r\n<div id=\"article\">\r\n    <!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC \"-//W3C//DTD XHTML 1.0 Transitional//EN\">\n\n<div class=\"menu\" id=\"bloc\"><ul>\n<li><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#top_full\">Top</a></li>\n<li><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#abs\">Abstract</a></li>\n<li><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#S1\">1. Introduction</a></li>\n<li><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#S2\">2. Data</a></li>\n<li><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#S16\" title=\"An unusual strong lensing system\">3. An unusual ...</a></li>\n<li><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#S22\">4. RV4 as a starburst galaxy</a></li>\n<li><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#S27\" title=\"Interpreting the short depletion time\">5. Interpreting the ...</a></li>\n<li><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#S28\">6. Conclusion</a></li>\n<li><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#ack\">Acknowledgments</a></li>\n<li><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#ref\">References</a></li>\n<li><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#tabs\">List of tables</a></li>\n<li><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#figs\">List of figures</a></li>\n</ul></div>\n<div id=\"contenu\">\n<a name=\"top_full\"></a><div id=\"head\">A&amp;A 635, A27 (2020)<h2 class=\"title\">A hyper luminous starburst at <i>z</i> = 4.72 magnified by a lensing galaxy pair at <i>z</i> = 1.48</h2>\n<div class=\"article-authors\"><p class=\"bold\"><span id=\"aa36727-19-author-1\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201936727&amp;n=1\" class=\"author\">L. Ciesla</span><sup>1</sup><sup>,2</sup>, <span id=\"aa36727-19-author-2\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201936727&amp;n=2\" class=\"author\">M. B&#233;thermin</span><sup>1</sup>, <span id=\"aa36727-19-author-3\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201936727&amp;n=3\" class=\"author\">E. Richard</span><sup>3</sup>, <span id=\"aa36727-19-author-5\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201936727&amp;n=5\" class=\"author\">T. Diaz-Santos</span><sup>4</sup>, <span id=\"aa36727-19-author-6\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201936727&amp;n=6\" class=\"author\">M. T. Wang</span><sup>7</sup>, <span id=\"aa36727-19-author-10\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201936727&amp;n=10\" class=\"author\">C. Schreiber</span><sup>8</sup>, <span id=\"aa36727-19-author-11\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201936727&amp;n=11\" class=\"author\">C. Yang</span><sup>9</sup>, <span id=\"aa36727-19-author-12\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201936727&amp;n=12\" class=\"author\">J. Zabl</span><sup>3</sup>, <span id=\"aa36727-19-author-13\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201936727&amp;n=13\" class=\"author\">M. Fraser</span><sup>10</sup>, <span id=\"aa36727-19-author-14\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201936727&amp;n=14\" class=\"author\">M. Aravena</span><sup>4</sup>, <span id=\"aa36727-19-author-15\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201936727&amp;n=15\" class=\"author\">R. J. Charmandaris</span><sup>12</sup><sup>,13</sup>, <span id=\"aa36727-19-author-22\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201936727&amp;n=22\" class=\"author\">P. C&#244;t&#233;</span><sup>14</sup>, <span id=\"aa36727-19-author-23\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201936727&amp;n=23\" class=\"author\">B. Gobat</span><sup>15</sup> and <span id=\"aa36727-19-author-26\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201936727&amp;n=26\" class=\"author\">O. Ilbert</span><sup>1</sup></p></div>\n<p class=\"aff\">\n<sup>1</sup> \n \nAix Marseille Univ., CNRS, CNES, LAM,  Marseille,  France \n \n\n<br>e-mail: laure.ciesla@lam.fr<br>\n<sup>2</sup> \n \nLaboratoire AIM-Paris-Saclay, CEA/DSM/Irfu &#8211; CNRS &#8211; Universit&#233; Paris Diderot, CEA-Saclay,  91191   Gif-sur-Yvette,  France \n \n<br>\n<sup>3</sup> \n \nUniv Lyon, Univ Lyon1, ENS de Lyon, CNRS, Centre de Recherche Astrophysique de Lyon UMR5574,  69230   Saint-Genis-Laval,  France \n \n<br>\n<sup>4</sup> \n \nN&#250;cleo de Astronom&#237;a, Facultad de Ingenier&#237;a y Ciencias, Universidad Diego Portales,  Ej&#233;rcito Libertador 441,  Santiago   8320000,  Chile \n \n<br>\n<sup>5</sup> \n \nAstronomy Centre, Department of Physics and Astronomy, University of Sussex,  Brighton   BN1 9QH,  UK \n \n<br>\n<sup>6</sup> \n \nCentro de Astronom&#237;a (CITEVA), Universidad de Antofagasta,  Avenida Angamos 601,  Antofagasta,  Chile \n \n<br>\n<sup>7</sup> \n \nInstitute of Astronomy, Graduate School of Science, The University of Tokyo,  2-21-1 Osawa,  Mitaka,  Tokyo   181-0015,  Japan \n \n<br>\n<sup>8</sup> \n \nDepartment of Physics, University of Oxford,  Keble Road,  Oxford   OX1 3RH,  UK \n \n<br>\n<sup>9</sup> \n \n European Southern Observatory, Alonso de C&#243;rdova 3107, Casilla,  19001   Vitacura,  Santiago,  Chile \n \n<br>\n<sup>10</sup> \n \nSchool of Physics, O&#8217;Brien Centre for Science North, University College Dublin,  Belfield,  Dublin 4,  Ireland \n \n<br>\n<sup>11</sup> \n \nDepartment of Physics and Astronomy, Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey,  136 Frelinghuysen Road,  Piscataway,  NJ   08854-8019,  USA \n \n<br>\n<sup>12</sup> \n \nDepartment of Physics, University of Crete,  71003   Heraklion,  Greece \n \n<br>\n<sup>13</sup> \n \nInstitute of Astrophysics, Foundation for Research and Technology-Hellas,  71110   Heraklion,  Greece \n \n<br>\n<sup>14</sup> \n \n National Research Council, 5071 W. Saanich Road,  Victoria,  BC   V9E 2E7,  Canada \n \n<br>\n<sup>15</sup> \n \nInstituto de F&#237;sica, Pontificia Universidad Cat&#243;lica de Valpara&#237;so,  Casilla   4059,  Valpara&#237;so,  Chile \n \n<br></p>\n<p class=\"history\"><span class=\"bold\">Received: </span>\n18 \nSeptember \n2019\n<br><span class=\"bold\">Accepted: </span>\n9 \nJanuary \n2020\n</p>\n<p class=\"bold\"><a name=\"abs\"></a>Abstract</p>\n<p>We serendipitously discovered in the <i>Herschel</i> Reference Survey an extremely bright infrared source with <i>S</i><sub>500</sub>&#8196;&#8764;&#8196;120 mJy in the line of sight of the Virgo cluster which we name Red Virgo 4 (RV4). Based on IRAM/EMIR and IRAM/NOEMA detections of the CO(5&#8722;4), CO(4&#8722;3), and [CI] lines, RV4 is located at a redshift of 4.724, yielding a total observed infrared luminosity of 1.1 &#177; 0.6 &#215; 10<sup>14</sup> <i>L</i><sub>&#8857;</sub>. At the position of the <i>Herschel</i> emission, three blobs are detected with the VLA at 10 cm. The CO(5&#8722;4) line detection of each blob confirms that they are at the same redshift with the same line width, indicating that they are multiple images of the same source. In <i>Spitzer</i> and deep optical observations, two sources, High-<i>z</i> Lens 1 (HL1) West and HL1 East, are detected at the center of the three VLA/NOEMA blobs. These two sources are placed at <i>z</i>&#8196;=&#8196;1.48 with X-shooter spectra, suggesting that they could be merging and gravitationally lensing the emission of RV4. HL1 is the second most distant lens known to date in strong lensing systems. Constrained by the position of the three VLA/NOEMA blobs, the Einstein radius of the lensing system is 2.2&#8243; &#177; 0.2 (20 kpc). The high redshift of HL1 and the large Einstein radius are highly unusual for a strong lensing system. In this paper, we present the insterstellar medium properties of the background source RV4. Different estimates of the gas depletion time yield low values suggesting that RV4 is a starburst galaxy. Among all high-<i>z</i> submillimeter galaxies, this source exhibits one of the lowest <i>L</i><sub>[CI]</sub> to <i>L</i><sub>IR</sub> ratios, 3.2 &#177; 0.9 &#215; 10<sup>&#8722;6</sup>, suggesting an extremely short gas depletion time of only 14 &#177; 5 Myr. It also shows a relatively high <i>L</i><sub>[CI]</sub> to <i>L</i><sub>CO(4&#8722;3)</sub> ratio (0.7 &#177; 0.2) and low <i>L</i><sub>CO(5&#8722;4)</sub> to <i>L</i><sub>IR</sub> ratio (only &#8764;50% of the value expected for normal galaxies) hinting at low density of gas. Finally, we discuss the short depletion time of RV4. It can be explained by either a very high star formation efficiency, which is difficult to reconcile with major mergers simulations of high-<i>z</i> galaxies, or a rapid decrease of star formation, which would bias the estimate of the depletion time toward an artificially low value.</p>\n<div class=\"kword\"><p><span class=\"bold\">Key words: </span>galaxies: high-redshift / galaxies: ISM / galaxies: starburst / galaxies: star formation / submillimeter: galaxies</p></div>\n</div>\n<p><i>&#169; L. Ciesla et al. 2020</i></p>\n<p><a rel=\"license\" href=\"https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0\"><img alt=\"Licence Creative Commons\" src=\"https://i.creativecommons.org/l/by/4.0/88x31.png\"></a><br>Open Access article, <a href=\"https://www.edpsciences.org\" target=\"_blank\">published by EDP Sciences</a>, under the terms of the Creative Commons Attribution License (<a href=\"https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0\" target=\"_blank\">https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0</a>), which permits unrestricted use, distribution, and reproduction in any medium, provided the original work is properly cited.</p>\n<h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"S1\"></a>1. Introduction</h2>\n<p>In the local Universe, a third of the total bolometric luminosity of galaxies is emitted in the infrared (IR) and submillimetric (submm) domains by dust grains, which reprocess the energy absorbed from the stars and active galactic nuclei (AGN; <a name=\"InR109\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R109\">Soifer &amp; Neugebauer 1991</a>). In submm galaxies (SMGs, <a name=\"InR106\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R106\">Smail et al. 1997</a>; <a name=\"InR6\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R6\">Barger et al. 1998</a>), which are highly dust-obscured systems, the energy balance between optical and IR/submm domains is skewed even more towards long-wavelength emission. The dust is heated by numerous young stars causing the SMGs to be extremely bright in the submm regime and reach huge IR luminosities (<i>L</i><sub>IR</sub>) higher than &#8764;10<sup>12</sup> <i>L</i><sub>&#8857;</sub>. More and more of these extreme star-forming galaxies are being found (for instance, <a name=\"InR36\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R36\">Daddi et al. 2009</a>; <a name=\"InR84\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R84\">Negrello et al. 2010</a>; <a name=\"InR56\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R56\">Frayer et al. 2011</a>; <a name=\"InR127\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R127\">Yun et al. 2012</a>; <a name=\"InR94\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R94\">Riechers et al. 2013</a>; <a name=\"InR123\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R123\">Wei&#223; et al. 2013</a>; <a name=\"InR63\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R63\">Ivison et al. 2013</a>; <a name=\"InR120\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R120\">Vieira et al. 2013</a>; <a name=\"InR46\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R46\">Dowell et al. 2014</a>; <a name=\"InR19\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R19\">Ca&#241;ameras et al. 2015</a>; <a name=\"InR45\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R45\">D&#237;az-Santos et al. 2016</a>; <a name=\"InR112\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R112\">Strandet et al. 2017</a>; <a name=\"InR77\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R77\">Marrone et al. 2018</a>; <a name=\"InR128\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R128\">Zavala et al. 2018</a>). Among these, many are sources at <i>z</i>&#8196;&gt; &#8196;4, indicating an extremely rapid assembly of these structures. Their high star formation rates (SFRs) suggest the presence of large gas reservoirs (for instance, a gas fraction of &#8764;50%; <a name=\"InR57\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R57\">Fu et al. 2013</a>; <a name=\"InR9\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R9\">B&#233;thermin et al. 2015</a>; <a name=\"InR5\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R5\">Aravena et al. 2016</a>) and their large dust content indicates that their interstellar medium (ISM) is metal enriched. One of the challenges posed by these sources is to understand how this massive and mature ISM can be in place so early in these galaxies. Indeed, these massive galaxies are still not well reproduced by cosmological simulations (<a name=\"InR41\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R41\">Dav&#233; et al. 2010</a>; <a name=\"InR31\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R31\">Cousin et al. 2015</a>; <a name=\"InR110\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R110\">Sparre et al. 2015</a>). The study of these starbursting systems, which usually lie above the main-sequence of star-forming galaxies (for instance, <a name=\"InR87\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R87\">Noeske et al. 2007</a>; <a name=\"InR51\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R51\">Elbaz et al. 2007</a>, <a name=\"InR52\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R52\">2011</a>) and whose mid-IR properties resemble those of the very brightest, nearby IR-luminous galaxies (<a name=\"InR44\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R44\">D&#237;az-Santos et al. 2011</a>), is of paramount importance for providing constraints on models of the formation and evolution of massive galaxies. In fact, the massive ellipticals that we observe in the local Universe could have formed rapidly &#8764;10 Gyr ago and be the remnant of this population of starbursting galaxies at high redshift (<a name=\"InR78\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R78\">McCarthy et al. 2004</a>; <a name=\"InR34\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R34\">Daddi et al. 2007a</a>, <a name=\"InR35\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R35\">2007b</a>; <a name=\"InR115\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R115\">Tacconi et al. 2008</a>; <a name=\"InR28\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R28\">Cimatti et al. 2008</a>; <a name=\"InR59\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R59\">Haan et al. 2013</a>). Within this scenario, because of their tremendous SFRs, the most vigorously star-forming SMGs rapidly quench their star formation by exhausting their gas reservoir in only a few hundred Myr, making them very rare. For instance, <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R57\">Fu et al. (2013)</a> estimate the space density of SMGs with SFR &gt; 2000 <i>M</i><sub>&#8857;</sub> yr<sup>&#8722;1</sup> to be 1.4 &#215; 10<sup>&#8722;5</sup> Mpc<sup>&#8722;3</sup>.</p>\n<p>Nevertheless, samples of SMGs have been built with facilities like the South Pole Telescope (SPT) and the <i>Herschel</i> Space Observatory (for instance, <a name=\"InR50\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R50\">Eales et al. 2010</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R84\">Negrello et al. 2010</a>; <a name=\"InR18\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R18\">Bussmann et al. 2013</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R123\">Wei&#223; et al. 2013</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R120\">Vieira et al. 2013</a>), and statistical studies of their properties can be now found in the literature. Studies of high-<i>z</i> bright SMGs (<i>S</i><sub>850</sub>&#8196;&gt; &#8196;50 mJy) show that the majority of these sources are gravitationally lensed by foreground, massive galaxies, thus amplifying the background source emission. This magnification allows us to detect high-redshift galaxies that could have been otherwise missed or observed with a lower signal-to-noise ratio (S/N). The ISM of high-<i>z</i> sources can thus be studied through the easier detection of lines, thanks to flux boosting (for instance, <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R123\">Wei&#223; et al. 2013</a>; <a name=\"InR1\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R1\">Alaghband-Zadeh et al. 2013</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R9\">B&#233;thermin et al. 2015</a>; <a name=\"InR15\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R15\">Bothwell et al. 2017</a>; <a name=\"InR124\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R124\">Yang et al. 2017</a>; <a name=\"InR32\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R32\">Cunningham et al. 2019</a>). Another aspect of gravitational lensing is that the deflection of the light emitted by a background source allows us to probe the mass distribution of the foreground source acting as the lens, constraining dark matter (DM) sub-halo structures (<a name=\"InR61\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R61\">Hezaveh et al. 2016</a>) as well as the initial mass function (IMF; <a name=\"InR20\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R20\">Ca&#241;ameras et al. 2017</a>), for instance. Finally, gravitational lensing boosts the angular resolution with which we can observe background sources allowing spatially resolved studies of the ISM of high redshift galaxies (for instance, <a name=\"InR114\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R114\">Swinbank et al. 2015</a>; <a name=\"InR21\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R21\">Ca&#241;ameras et al. 2018</a>; <a name=\"InR74\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R74\">Litke et al. 2019</a>; <a name=\"InR125\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R125\">Yang et al. 2019a</a>; <a name=\"InR4\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R4\">Apostolovski et al. 2019</a>).</p>\n<p>In this study, we report the discovery of a peculiar strong lensing system. The high-<i>z</i> galaxy, HRS188.6868+7.1357, hereafter Red Virgo 4 (RV4), was first detected in a survey of local galaxies carried out with <i>Herschel</i>/SPIRE (<a name=\"InR58\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R58\">Griffin et al. 2010</a>; <a name=\"InR12\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R12\">Boselli et al. 2010</a>). It is detected in the background of the SPIRE pointing of IC 3521 at RA: 188.6868 and Dec: +7.1357 (J2000). The high flux density (122 mJy at 500 <i>&#956;</i>m) as well as the redward increasing spectrum led to interest in this source. We gathered and obtained ancillary data to constrain its infrared (IR) emission, measured its redshift, identified the foreground source acting as a lens (High-<i>z</i> Lens 1, HL1, which turned to be one of the most distant lenses found until now), and constrained the strong lensing system.</p>\n<p>In Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#S2\">2</a>, we list the set of ancillary data spanning from optical to radio, with both spectroscopic and photometric observations. The analysis of the data resulting in the lensing configuration conclusion is presented in Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#S16\">3</a>. The depletion time in particular is discussed in Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#S27\">5</a>. The characterization of RV4 is developed in Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#S22\">4</a>, and conclusions are given in Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#S28\">6</a>. A companion paper focusing on a detailed lens model and on the nature of HL1 is in preparation.</p>\n<p>Throughout the paper, we use the &#923;CDM cosmology of <a name=\"InR90\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R90\">Planck Collaboration XIII (2016)</a> and a <a name=\"InR95\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R95\">Salpeter (1955)</a> IMF.</p>\n<h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"S2\"></a>2. Data</h2>\n<p>In this section, we describe the set of data that we obtained for the characterization of the lensing system composed of RV4 and HL1.</p>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S3\"></a>2.1. Unresolved observations of RV4</h3>\n<h4 class=\"sec3\">\n<a name=\"S4\"></a>2.1.1. Herschel</h4>\n<p>RV4 is detected in the background of the SPIRE (Spectral and Photometric Imaging Receiver) images of IC 3521, a Virgo cluster galaxy observed as part of the <i>Herschel</i> Reference Survey (HRS, <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R12\">Boselli et al. 2010</a>) and the <i>Herschel</i> Virgo Cluster Survey (<a name=\"InR42\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R42\">Davies et al. 2010</a>). As shown in Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#F1\">1</a>, RV4 appears as a particularly bright, red source in SPIRE imaging of IC 3521, clearly contrasting with the foreground galaxy.</p>\n<p><a name=\"F1\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/F1.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19-fig1_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/F1.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 1.</span></a><p><i>Left panel</i>: <i>Herschel</i>/SPIRE RGB color image (red: 500 <i>&#956;</i>m; green: 350 <i>&#956;</i>m; blue: 250 <i>&#956;</i>m). <i>Right panel</i>: VLA 3 GHz detections of RV4. The SPIRE emission splits into three unresolved sources at 3 GHz. The beam size is indicated by the white ellipse.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=1&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201936727\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n</table></div></p>\n<p>The FWHMs of the 250, 350, and 500 <i>&#956;</i>m maps of IC 3521 are 18.2&#8243;, 24.5&#8243;, and 36.0&#8243;, respectively (<a name=\"InR25\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R25\">Ciesla et al. 2012</a>). RV4 is not resolved in these SPIRE images, and flux densities are extracted using the timeline-based PSF fitting approach which is the most appropriate method for point-like <i>Herschel</i> sources (<a name=\"InR7\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R7\">Bendo et al. 2013</a>). RV4&#8217;s SPIRE flux densities are provided in Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#T2\">2</a>. We refer the reader to <a name=\"InR108\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R108\">Smith et al. (2012)</a> for a complete description of the SPIRE data reduction made as part of the HRS.</p>\n<p>IC 3521 has also been observed with PACS (Photodetector Array Camera and Spectrometer; <a name=\"InR91\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R91\">Poglitsch et al. 2010</a>) at 100 and 160 <i>&#956;</i>m (<a name=\"InR30\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R30\">Cortese et al. 2014</a>). RV4 is not detected in the PACS images, and the derived upper limits (see Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#T2\">2</a>) do not provide any useful constraint on the IR spectral energy distribution (SED).</p>\n<h4 class=\"sec3\">\n<a name=\"S5\"></a>2.1.2. IRAM 30 m/NIKA</h4>\n<p>After its initial detection by <i>Herschel</i>, we used the NIKA camera (Neel-IRAM-KID-Array; <a name=\"InR81\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R81\">Monfardini et al. 2010</a>) on the 30 m telescope at Pico de Valeta (Spain) to follow up on RV4 (234-14, PI: M. B&#233;thermin) at 1.2 and 2 mm. Nine Lissajous scans of five minutes each were performed to detect the source and the data were reduced using the standard pipeline. At the IRAM 30 m telescope&#8217;s resolution at these wavelengths (&#8764;12&#8243; and 18&#8243; at 1.2 and 2 mm, respectively), the RV4 system is unresolved; therefore, a standard PSF-fitting extraction is used. Flux densities are provided in Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#T2\">2</a>.</p>\n<h4 class=\"sec3\">\n<a name=\"S6\"></a>2.1.3. GBT/Zpectrometer</h4>\n<p>We obtained 6 h of GBT<sup><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#FN2\">1</a></sup>/Zpectrometer observations of RV4 (GBT14A-162, PI: L. Ciesla) to measure its spectroscopic redshift. The observations were carried out on March 1st, 2014. We aimed at the detection of the CO(1&#8722;0) line in the frequency range of the Zpectrometer (25.6&#8722;36.1 GHz), covering 2.1&#8196;&lt; &#8196;<i>z</i>&#8196;&lt; &#8196;3.5 with a spectral resolution of 32 MHz per channel. No line was detected in the observations. Nevertheless, these observations allowed us to narrow the range of redshift solutions for RV4, and thus pinpoint the true redshift of the source.</p>\n<h4 class=\"sec3\">\n<a name=\"S7\"></a>2.1.4. IRAM 30 m/EMIR</h4>\n<p>We obtained 6 h of IRAM 30 m telescope DDT time (D07-15, PI: L. Ciesla) aiming at the detection of CO(5&#8722;4) and CO(4&#8722;3) to measure the redshift of RV4. The observations were made on February 24 and March 1 of 2016 with EMIR in band E090 (3 mm) over the 80&#8722;111 GHz frequency range with a spectral resolution &#916;<i>v</i> of 50 km s<sup>&#8722;1</sup>. The wide-band line multiple auto-correlator (WILMA) and the fast Fourier Transform Spectrometer (FTS-200) were used simultaneously as backends during the observations. Bright planet/quasar calibrators including Jupiter and J1226+023 were used for pointing and focusing. The weather conditions were excellent with <i>&#964;</i><sub>225&#8198;GHz</sub>&#8196;&#8818;&#8196;0.2, reaching a sensitivity of &#8818;0.6 mK per 50 km s<sup>&#8722;1</sup> and a system temperature of &#8818;100 K. The data were calibrated using the standard dual method. Data were then reduced with the <tt>GILDAS</tt><sup><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#FN3\">2</a></sup> package <tt>CLASS</tt>. The baseline-removed spectral scans were co-added according to the weights derived from the noise levels of each. We also include &#8764;10% absolute flux calibration uncertainty in our overall uncertainty. Line fluxes are provided in Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#T1\">1</a>.</p>\n<p><a name=\"T1\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><div class=\"ligne\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/T1.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Table 1.</span></a><p>Submillimeter lines properties of RV4.</p>\n</div></div></p>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S8\"></a>2.2. High resolution observations of RV4</h3>\n<h4 class=\"sec3\">\n<a name=\"S9\"></a>2.2.1. VLA</h4>\n<p>To spatially resolve the emission of RV4, we obtained 9.5 h (7.4 h on source) of Karl G. Jansky Very Large Array<sup><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#FN4\">3</a></sup> (VLA) time (VLA/2014-06-044, PI: L. Ciesla) in A-configuration with 28 antennas at 3 GHz (<i>S</i>-band, 2.0 GHz&#8722;3.9 GHz), reaching a sensitivity of 2 <i>&#956;</i>Jy beam<sup>&#8722;1</sup> and a beam size of 0.65&#8243;. The observations were carried out from August 3rd to August 22nd 2015. The data were calibrated by the observatory pipeline. We produced a continuum image using the CASA software (<a name=\"InR79\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R79\">McMullin et al. 2007</a>). We used all the channels to produce a continuum map and maximize the S/N. We used Briggs weighting with robust = 0.5 to achieve a good compromise between sensitivity (2.6 <i>&#956;</i>Jy beam<sup>&#8722;1</sup>) and angular resolution (0.68&#8243; &#215; 0.55&#8243;). The flux densities of the detections are provided in Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#T2\">2</a>.</p>\n<p><a name=\"T2\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><div class=\"ligne\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/T2.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Table 2.</span></a><p>Submillimeter photometry of RV4.</p>\n</div></div></p>\n<h4 class=\"sec3\">\n<a name=\"S10\"></a>2.2.2. NOEMA</h4>\n<p>We obtained 6 h (3.1 h on source) of PolyFiX NOEMA data (W17EG002, PI: L. Ciesla) to map the CO(5&#8722;4) emission at observed-frame 100.6 GHz, in the 3 mm band (A-configuration, 9 antennas, 82.9&#8722;90.6 GHz and 98.4&#8722;106.1 GHz), with a native resolution of 2 MHz, that we later rebinned by a factor of 8 before imaging. Observations were carried out on February 6th and 9th, 2017. We reached a sensitivity of 13 <i>&#956;</i>Jy beam<sup>&#8722;1</sup> with a spectral resolution of 167.8 MHz per channel, and a spatial resolution of 1.56&#8243; &#215; 0.84&#8243;. The data were calibrated using the <tt>GILDAS/CLIC</tt> package. The data cubes and continuum maps were generated using <tt>GILDAS/MAPPING</tt>. Because of the very large band width of Polyfix, we imaged separately the continuum in the lower and upper side bands. Both CO(5&#8722;4) and [CI] (492.161 GHz rest frame) lines are clearly detected (see Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#S17\">3.1</a>).</p>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S11\"></a>2.3. Observations of HL1</h3>\n<h4 class=\"sec3\">\n<a name=\"S12\"></a>2.3.1. Spitzer</h4>\n<p>Mid-IR data from <i>Spitzer</i>/IRAC (InfraRed Array Camera) are available only at 3.6 and 4.5 <i>&#956;</i>m, acquired as part of the <i>Spitzer</i> Survey of Stellar Structure in Galaxies (S4G; <a name=\"InR103\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R103\">Sheth et al. 2010</a>), and were downloaded from the NASA/IPAC Infrared Science Archive<sup><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#FN5\">4</a></sup>. We refer the reader to <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R103\">Sheth et al. (2010)</a>, <a name=\"InR83\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R83\">Mu&#241;oz-Mateos et al. (2013)</a>, and <a name=\"InR92\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R92\">Querejeta et al. (2015)</a> for detailed descriptions of the data acquisition and reduction. No observation with IRAC3 and 4, nor with MIPS, is available at the coordinates of RV4.</p>\n<h4 class=\"sec3\">\n<a name=\"S13\"></a>2.3.2. CFHT data from NGVS</h4>\n<p>Deep ground-based optical images of the Virgo cluster are available as part of the Next Generation Virgo cluster Survey (NGVS; <a name=\"InR55\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R55\">Ferrarese et al. 2012</a>) obtained with MegaPrime (CFHT). The region around RV4 has been observed in <i>u</i><sup>*</sup>, <i>g</i>&#8242;, <i>i</i>&#8242;, and <i>z</i>&#8242; bands. The depths for a point source with S/N of 10 are 25.9, 25.7, 24.9, and 24.6 AB mag, in the <i>u</i><sup>*</sup>, <i>g</i>&#8242;, <i>i</i>&#8242;, and <i>z</i>&#8242; bands, respectively. We refer the reader to <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R55\">Ferrarese et al. (2012)</a> and <a name=\"InR73\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R73\">Licitra et al. (2016)</a> for detailed information on the data acquisition and reduction.</p>\n<h4 class=\"sec3\">\n<a name=\"S14\"></a>2.3.3. Magellan/FOURSTAR</h4>\n<p>We observed HL1 in March 2018 with the near-infrared imager Fourstar on the 6.5 m <i>Magellan</i> Baade telescope using a random-position dither pattern. Three filters were used: J1 (corresponding to the <i>Y</i> band), <i>J</i>, and <i>Ks</i>, with integrations of 44.8, 38.4, and 15.1 min, respectively. These data were initially calibrated with the FSRED pipeline.</p>\n<h4 class=\"sec3\">\n<a name=\"S15\"></a>2.3.4. VLT/X-shooter</h4>\n<p>We obtained 6 h of VLT/X-shooter (<a name=\"InR119\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R119\">Vernet et al. 2011</a>) time as part of cycle 97A (097.A-0511, PI: T. Diaz-Santos) aiming to achieve an S/N of 5 in the 1.5&#8722;2.2 <i>&#956;</i>m range (NIR arm). The observations were carried out on February 1 to 7, 2017. The total effective integration time of 4.8 h and 4.5 h in NIR and VIS arms, respectively, was split between six OBs with four nodding positions (ABBA) each. Due to a telescope pointing issue, we needed to reject one of the 6 OBs. We reduced each of the remaining 20 nodding pairs (AB) separately using the X-shooter pipeline (<a name=\"InR80\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R80\">Modigliani et al. 2010</a>). We flux-calibrated the data using standard pipeline recipes applied to observations of flux standard stars taken during each night of the observations. In addition, we corrected the data for telluric absorption using a model atmospheric transmittance spectrum created with <span class=\"smallcaps\">MOLECFIT</span> (<a name=\"InR107\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R107\">Smette et al. 2015</a>; <a name=\"InR67\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R67\">Kausch et al. 2015</a>) from observations of telluric standard stars taken close in time and airmass to the science observations. Subsequently, we optimally combined the individual nodding pairs (2D spectra) with a weighted average using our scripts. Our scripts also corrected the wavelength scale to vacuum and removed the heliocentric velocity. Finally, we extracted 1D spectra from the resulting 2D master spectrum. The 1.2&#8243; slits provide a nominal spectral resolution of <i>R</i>&#8196;=&#8196;6500 and <i>R</i>&#8196;=&#8196;4300 in VIS and NIR, respectively.</p>\n<h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"S16\"></a>3. An unusual strong lensing system</h2>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S17\"></a>3.1. Red Virgo 4: a magnified SMG</h3>\n<p>RV4 was originally detected in the field of view of the <i>Herschel</i>/SPIRE pointing observation of IC 3521 (Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#F1\">1</a>, left panel). RV4 is unresolved in the three bands, and the SPIRE flux densities are 78.4 &#177; 8.9, 118.4 &#177; 10.9, and 122.8 &#177; 11.1 mJy at 250, 350, and 500 <i>&#956;</i>m, respectively. The NIKA millimeter flux density ratio excludes the possibility of a low-<i>z</i> radio AGN and confirms the high-<i>z</i> nature of this emission with fluxes 21.1 &#177; 1.2 and 6.0 &#177; 0.2 mJy at 1 mm and 2 mm, respectively, placing the IR peak of the SED between 350 and 500 <i>&#956;</i>m. The redshift of RV4 is provided by the detection of the CO(5&#8722;4), CO(4&#8722;3), and [CI](<sup>3</sup>P<sub>1</sub>&#8594;<sup>3</sup>P<sub>0</sub>) lines with 30 m/EMIR (Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#F2\">2</a>), yielding a spectroscopic redshift of 4.72401 &#177; 0.00042.</p>\n<p><a name=\"F2\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/F2.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19-fig2_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/F2.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 2.</span></a><p>[CI](1&#8722;0), CO(4&#8722;3), and CO(5&#8722;4) emission lines detected with 30 m/EMIR at the RV4 position. They correspond to the integrated emission of the three VLA/NOEMA blobs. The red solid lines shows the best fit of Gaussian.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=2&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201936727\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n</table></div></p>\n<p>Combining the SPIRE and NIKA observations and the spectroscopic redshift of RV4, we derive a total IR luminosity of 1.07 &#177; 0.19 &#215; 10<sup>14</sup> <i>L</i><sub>&#8857;</sub> from IR SED fitting (see Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#S23\">4.1</a>). The high <i>S</i><sub>500</sub> flux density is above the 100 mJy <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R84\">Negrello et al. (2010)</a> lens selection threshold, above which the probability for a SMG to be lensed is very high. This strongly suggests the presence of multiple sources contributing to the submm fluxes (for instance, <a name=\"InR62\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R62\">Hodge et al. 2013</a>) or a magnification from lensing (for instance, <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R84\">Negrello et al. 2010</a>). The SPIRE/NIKA emission is resolved by VLA A-configuration observations at 3 GHz/10 cm into three sources, hereafter named A, B, and C (Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#F1\">1</a>, right panel). The measured 10 cm continuum flux densities are 34.3 &#177; 4.6, 31.2 &#177; 4.9, and 19.8 &#177; 6.3 <i>&#956;</i>Jy for sources A, B, and C, respectively.</p>\n<p>We determine the spectroscopic redshift of each of the three blobs from NOEMA/PolyFix observations using the CO(5&#8722;4) emission line. The [CI](1&#8722;0) line is also detected but only for blob A and B; the [CI] to CO(5&#8722;4) line ratio is equivalent for both blobs, at 0.27 &#177; 0.04 and 0.26 &#177; 0.04 for blob A and B, respectively. For each blob, and for the CO(5&#8722;4) and [CI](1&#8722;0) lines, we measure the redshift using the <span class=\"smallcaps\">SLINEFIT</span><sup><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#FN6\">5</a></sup> code (<a name=\"InR99\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R99\">Schreiber et al. 2018</a>). As shown in Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#F3\">3</a>, the CO(5&#8722;4) lines of blob A and B are at nearly the exact same frequency (100.683 GHz and 100.680 GHz) with the same width (627 &#177; 55 km s<sup>&#8722;1</sup> and 622 &#177; 67 km s<sup>&#8722;1</sup>). The redshift of blob C is slightly offset with a CO(5&#8722;4) line at 100.66 GHz. These frequencies translate into <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19-eq1.gif\"></span>, <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19-eq2.gif\"></span>, and <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19-eq3.gif\"></span>, for blobs A, B, and C, respectively. The errors quoted in the redshift measurements are underestimated, as the uncertainties from the line profiles are not included. Indeed, as discussed in different studies based on simulations (for instance, <a name=\"InR60\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R60\">Hezaveh et al. 2012</a>; <a name=\"InR101\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R101\">Serjeant 2012</a>) and observations (for instance, <a name=\"InR93\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R93\">Riechers et al. 2008</a>; <a name=\"InR49\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R49\">Dye et al. 2015</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R124\">Yang et al. 2017</a>, <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R125\">2019a</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R4\">Apostolovski et al. 2019</a>), the magnification can significantly vary along the velocity channels from blue to red and thus heavily distort the intrinsic line profile. This differential lensing effect may also cause different line profiles in different images. This effect could be related to the redshift offset of blob C, which might be caused by a higher magnification of the blue part of the line. Although the [CI](1&#8722;0) line is weaker, the line frequencies of blobs A and B are consistent with a single redshift. As for CO(5&#8722;4), the [CI](1&#8722;0) redshift of blob C seems to be offset, but in this case the line S/N is too low (&#8776;2) for a meaningful comparison.</p>\n<p><a name=\"F3\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/F3.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19-fig3_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/F3.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 3.</span></a><p><i>Top panel</i>: NOEMA observations of CO(5&#8722;4) lines of blob A (red), B (purple), and C (blue). Inset panel: VLA 3 GHz image of RV4. <i>Bottom panel</i>: [CI](1&#8722;0) lines of blob A (red), B (purple), and C (blue). The inset panels show the redshift probability distribution functions obtained with <span class=\"smallcaps\">SLINEFIT</span>.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=3&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201936727\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n</table></div></p>\n<p>In Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#F4\">4</a>, we show that the positions of the NOEMA blobs are consistent with the VLA continuum positions. The CO(5&#8722;4) positions of blobs A and B are also consistent with the continuum detections. However, there seems to be a shift between the position of the CO(5&#8722;4) emission from blob C and its continuum counterparts. The separation between the two centers of emission is 0.29&#8243; &#177; 0.10&#8243;. In theory<sup><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#FN7\">6</a></sup>, for the CO(5&#8722;4) line, a 4.5 sigma detection has a position uncertainty of 0.17 &#215; 0.09&#8243;. The same uncertainty is expected for the continuum. Therefore, this spatial shift might not be significant.</p>\n<p><a name=\"F4\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/F4.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19-fig4_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/F4.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 4.</span></a><p>NOEMA 3 mm continuum observation of RV4. The CO(5&#8722;4) emission contours are shown in magenta while VLA contours are shown in black for comparison. The VLA and NOEMA beams are indicated by the black and magenta ellipses, respectively.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=4&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201936727\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n</table></div></p>\n<p>Considering the extreme IR luminosity of the system, the spatial distribution of the three blobs,and the identical CO(5&#8722;4) line profile (redshift and width) for each blob, we conclude that RV4 is a lensed <i>z</i>&#8196;=&#8196;4.72 submm galaxy, with A, B, and C, being multiple images of the same galaxy.</p>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S18\"></a>3.2. Identification of the lens</h3>\n<p>Two sources, hereafter denoted as High-<i>z</i> Lens 1 West (HL1-W) and High-<i>z</i> Lens 1 East (HL1-E), are clearly detected in the <i>u</i><sup>*</sup>, <i>g</i>&#8242;, <i>i</i>&#8242;, and <i>z</i>&#8242; bands. The two sources, which are only 2&#8243; apart, are slightly offset from the three VLA and IRAM/NOEMA blobs, by approximately 2.2&#8243; to the north (Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#F5\">5</a>, left panel). HL1-W and HL1-E are also clearly detected in IRAC imaging at 3.6 and 4.5 <i>&#956;</i>m (Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#F5\">5</a>, right panel).</p>\n<p><a name=\"F5\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/F5.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19-fig5_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/F5.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 5.</span></a><p><i>Left panel</i>: CFHT/<i>g</i>&#8242;, <i>i</i>&#8242;, and <i>z</i>&#8242; band images shown as a RGB image at the position of RV4. <i>Right panel</i>: <i>Spitzer</i>/IRAC1 image centered on the position of RV4. In both panels, the white contours indicate the positions of the three VLA detections. The positions of the <i>z</i>&#8196;=&#8196;1.48 lens system are indicated by the white arrows.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=5&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201936727\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n</table></div></p>\n<p>The <i>u</i><sup>*</sup> and <i>g</i>&#8242; bands probe shorter wavelengths than the Lyman break at <i>z</i>&#8196;=&#8196;4.72; thus we do not expect any emission from RV4 in these bands. Moreover, as shown by the VLA contours on the same figure, no <i>i</i>&#8242; or <i>z</i>&#8242; emission is seen from these three blobs either. The extended source detection limits of the NGVS are 26.3 and 25.8 AB mag arcsec<sup>&#8722;2</sup> (2<i>&#963;</i>) for the <i>i</i>&#8242; and <i>z</i>&#8242; band, respectively (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R55\">Ferrarese et al. 2012</a>). In the <i>Spitzer</i>/IRAC images, although the VLA detections are close to the outskirts of the IRAC emission of the lens system, no strong emission from RV4 is detected (Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#F5\">5</a>, right panel). Furthermore, the IRAC fluxes measured from PSF fitting for HL1-W and HL1-E are consistent with its SED, indicating no particular excess of flux that could be attributed to RV4.</p>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S19\"></a>3.3. Redshift determination for the lens</h3>\n<p>To determine the redshift of HL1-W and HL1-E, we obtained VLT/X-shooter observations of the system (Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#F6\">6</a>). The spectroscopic redshifts are measured using the software <span class=\"smallcaps\">SLINEFIT</span>. For HL1-E and HL1-W respectively, we obtain <i>z</i><sub>spec</sub> = 1.48379<span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19-eq4.gif\"></span> and <i>z</i><sub>spec</sub> = 1.48095<span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19-eq5.gif\"></span>, where the errors corresponds to uncertainties on the fits. The small errors on these spectroscopic redshifts are driven by high S/N detections of emission lines &#8211; the [OII] doublet (<i>S</i>/<i>N</i>&#8196;=&#8196;7.7), [OIII] doublet (<i>S</i>/<i>N</i>&#8196;=&#8196;3.3), [NII] doublet (<i>S</i>/<i>N</i>&#8196;=&#8196;11.4), H<i>&#945;</i> (<i>S</i>/<i>N</i>&#8196;=&#8196;5.3), and [SII] doublet (<i>S</i>/<i>N</i>&#8196;=&#8196;4.7) &#8211; as well as a detection of the continuum emission. These values reveal HL1-E/W as one of the most distant lens known in strong lensing systems and correspond to a velocity difference of 343 &#177; 38 km s<sup>&#8722;1</sup> indicating that HL1-E and HL1-W are probably merging together. The projected distance between the two blobs of 2&#8243; (17.4 kpc) is also consistent with merger scenario. In the literature, we find only one lens at a higher redshift presented in <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R20\">Ca&#241;ameras et al. (2017)</a> at <i>z</i><sub>spec</sub>&#8196;=&#8196;1.525, which is gravitationally lensing an SMG detected by <i>Planck</i>.</p>\n<p><a name=\"F6\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/F6.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19-fig6_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/F6.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 6.</span></a><p><i>Upper panel</i>: VLT/X-shooter 1D spectra of HL1-West. <i>Lower panel</i>: VLT/X-shooter 1D spectra of HL1-East. The inset panels show the probability distribution function for the redshift. The black lines are the best spectral fits obtained with <span class=\"smallcaps\">SLINEFIT</span>.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=6&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201936727\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n</table></div></p>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S20\"></a>3.4. Lensing properties</h3>\n<p>The data in hand allow us to obtain a better picture of the system in which RV4, at <i>z</i><sub>spec</sub>&#8196;=&#8196;4.72, is strongly lensed by a close pair of <i>z</i><sub>spec</sub>&#8196;=&#8196;1.48 galaxies. The redshifts of these sources as well as the positions of the multiple images of RV4 (A, B, and C) are used as constraints to provide a first order lens model. The redshifts of the lenses and sources as well as the centroids of images A, B and C are used to constrain a mass distribution assuming they arise from a multiply-imaged system. We use the <span class=\"smallcaps\">LENSTOOL</span><sup><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#FN8\">7</a></sup> software (<a name=\"InR71\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R71\">Kneib et al. 1996</a>; <a name=\"InR64\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R64\">Jullo et al. 2007</a>) to optimize a parametric model of the mass distribution reproducing the locations of the lensed images. The model parameters are presented in Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#T3\">3</a>. The modeling have been made following a Occam&#8217;s razor principle in the fact that this the simplest model able to correctly reproduce the positions of the VLA/NOEMA blobs as well as their flux ratios. A thorough model comparison will be presented in the second paper. Although the lens is composed of a pair of galaxies, we find that a simple model with a single dPIE (double Pseudo-Isothermal Elliptical) mass distribution provides a very good match, with an rms of 0.01&#8243; in the image plane. This simple model estimates the magnification to be 8.2 &#177; 2.5 with an Einstein radius, constrained by the positions of blobs A, B, and C, of 2.2&#8243; &#177; 0.2. The model provides magnifications of 3.4 &#177; 1.9, 2.6 &#177; 1.4, and 2.3 &#177; 0.8 for blobs A, B, and C, respectively.</p>\n<p><a name=\"T3\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><div class=\"ligne\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/T3.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Table 3.</span></a><p>Lensing modeling parameters.</p>\n</div></div></p>\n<p>We compare the redshifts and Einstein radii of other strong lensing systems found in the literature in Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#F7\">7</a>. In addition to being one of the most distant lenses known, HL1 has an Einstein radius of 2.2&#8243; &#177; 0.2 (20 kpc at <i>z</i>&#8196;=&#8196;1.48) that places it in a new region of the Einstein radius versus redshift plane (Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#F7\">7</a>).</p>\n<p><a name=\"F7\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/F7.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19-fig7_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/F7.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 7.</span></a><p>Einstein radii of lenses from the literature as a function of their redshift. The samples from the literature are: SL2S (<a name=\"InR82\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R82\">More et al. 2012</a>), SPT (<a name=\"InR111\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R111\">Spilker et al. 2016</a>), BELLS (<a name=\"InR104\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R104\">Shu et al. 2016</a>), MaNGA (<a name=\"InR117\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R117\">Talbot et al. 2018</a>), H-ATLAS (<a name=\"InR2\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R2\">Amvrosiadis et al. 2018</a>), and the sources of <a name=\"InR72\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R72\">Li et al. (2018)</a> and <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R20\">Ca&#241;ameras et al. (2017)</a>. The position of HL1 is marked by the red star. <i>Upper panel</i>: Einstein radius in arcsecond as a function of the redshift of the lens. Different symbols are from different samples of the literature. <i>Lower panel</i>: same as above, but with the Einstein radius expressed in kiloparsec. The density contours are built from the same sample of literature sources.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=7&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201936727\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n</table></div></p>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S21\"></a>3.5. Physical properties of the lens</h3>\n<p>To derive the physical properties of each component of HL1, we combine the photometric data (CFHT, FOURSTAR, <i>Spitzer</i>) with the X-shooter spectra. The X-shooter spectra are scaled using the <i>i</i>&#8242; band flux density for each blob and then integrated into a set of 10 artificial filters. We use the SED modeling code CIGALE (<a name=\"InR11\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R11\">Boquien et al. 2019</a>) to perform the SED fitting. We assume a <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R95\">Salpeter (1955)</a> IMF, a flexible delayed SFH (as described in <a name=\"InR27\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R27\">Ciesla et al. 2017</a>), <a name=\"InR17\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R17\">Bruzual &amp; Charlot (2003)</a> models, and a <a name=\"InR22\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R22\">Calzetti et al. (2000)</a> attenuation law. We find that HL1-W and HL1-E have stellar masses of 2.4 &#177; 0.4 &#215; 10<sup>11</sup> and 3.3 &#177; 0.6 &#215; 10<sup>11</sup> <i>M</i><sub>&#8857;</sub>, respectively. The SED fitting performed on the whole system using the integrated photometry of the two components yields a total stellar mass of 6.2 &#177; 1.0 &#215; 10<sup>11</sup> <i>M</i><sub>&#8857;</sub>.</p>\n<p>Although the stellar mass is well constrained thanks to FOURSTAR and <i>Spitzer</i> data, the SFR estimates for HL1-W and HL1-E are more uncertain due to the faintness of the two galaxies. The SED fitting results in SFRs of 9.2<span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19-eq12.gif\"></span> and 3.7<span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19-eq13.gif\"></span> <i>M</i><sub>&#8857;</sub> yr<sup>&#8722;1</sup> for HL1-W and HL1-E, respectively, where the errors reflect the difficulty of estimating the SFRs from the faint <i>g</i>&#8242; and <i>i</i>&#8242; emission. These values place the two counterparts below the MS of <a name=\"InR97\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R97\">Schreiber et al. (2015)</a> at <i>z</i>&#8196;=&#8196;1.5, as shown in Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#F8\">8</a>. However, we can probe the SF activity of these two sources using the H<i>&#945;</i> emission detected in the X-shooter spectra. As shown in Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#F6\">6</a>, HL1-W has no H<i>&#945;</i> emission, confirming the fact that HL1-W seems to be passive. On the other hand, HL1-E seems to have a large and strong H<i>&#945;</i> line with a line flux of 1.79 &#177; 0.33 &#215; 10<sup>&#8722;17</sup> erg s<sup>&#8722;1</sup> cm<sup>&#8722;2</sup> associated with a strong [NII] line with a flux of 4.33 &#177; 0.38 &#215; 10<sup>&#8722;17</sup> erg s<sup>&#8722;1</sup> cm<sup>&#8722;2</sup>. Furthermore, the H<i>&#946;</i> emission line is not detected whereas a strong [OIII] line with a flux of 2.40 &#177; 0.74 &#215; 10<sup>&#8722;17</sup> erg s<sup>&#8722;1</sup> cm<sup>&#8722;2</sup> is detected. These line fluxes, as well as the H<i>&#946;</i> upper limit, place HL1-E in the AGN region of the BPT diagram, as shown in Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#F9\">9</a>. Since HL1-E is likely hosting an AGN, we check if our measured stellar mass can be contaminated by AGN emission in the NIR. To do this, we use CIGALE to quantify the AGN fraction, defined as the contribution of the AGN to the total <i>L</i><sub>IR</sub> of the galaxy, which is a scaling factor for the AGN emission model. The methodology is fully described in <a name=\"InR26\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R26\">Ciesla et al. (2015)</a>. For HL1-E, the best <i>&#967;</i><sup>2</sup> model yields frac<sub>AGN</sub>&#8196;=&#8196;0, meaning that an AGN emission component is not needed to reproduce the host galaxy UV-NIR emission. Therefore, our stellar mass measurement is not contaminated by the AGN emission. We conclude that HL1-W and HL1-E seem to be passive as no strong star formation activity is detected from either continuum or line analysis.</p>\n<p><a name=\"F8\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/F8.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19-fig8_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/F8.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 8.</span></a><p>SED modeling of the two components of HL1 (HL1-W: <i>left panel</i>, HL1-E: <i>right panel</i>). The fit is performed using the filled symbols, circles are photometric points, and diamonds are points obtained averaging the X-shooter spectra over a range of wavelengths. The best fit to the data is shown as a solid line. The subpanels show the difference between the data points and the best-fit models. In each inset panel, we show the position of the component (plain color) in the SFR-<i>M</i><sub>*</sub> diagram along with the MS at <i>z</i>&#8196;=&#8196;1.5 from <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R97\">Schreiber et al. (2015)</a>. The position of the second component is also indicated in light color for comparison. Both components are located below the MS.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=8&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201936727\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n</table></div></p>\n<p><a name=\"F9\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/F9.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19-fig9_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/F9.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 9.</span></a><p>HL1-W (blue) and HL1-E (green) placed on the BPT diagram. The limit of <a name=\"InR70\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R70\">Kewley et al. (2013)</a> at <i>z</i>&#8196;=&#8196;1.5 is shown in grey.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr><td colspan=\"2\"><a href=\"http://dexter.edpsciences.org/applet.php?pdf_id=9&amp;DOI=10.1051/0004-6361/201936727\" target=\"DEXTER\">Open with DEXTER</a></td></tr>\n</table></div></p>\n<p>For the SED modeling, we adopt a <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R22\">Calzetti et al. (2000)</a> attenuation law, which is better suited for star-forming galaxies than for passive galaxies. However, <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R22\">Calzetti et al. (2000)</a> assume almost no attenuation in the NIR. Other attenuation laws such as <a name=\"InR24\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R24\">Charlot &amp; Fall (2000)</a> and <a name=\"InR75\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R75\">Lo Faro et al. (2017)</a> are characterized by a stronger attenuation in the NIR yielding larger stellar masses, by a factor of &#8764;1.3 (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R75\">Lo Faro et al. 2017</a>).</p>\n<h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"S22\"></a>4. RV4 as a starburst galaxy</h2>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S23\"></a>4.1. Infrared properties</h3>\n<p>The combination of the three SPIRE detections with the NIKA 1 mm and 2 mm flux densities provides a good sampling of the IR SED of RV4. Using the SED modeling code CIGALE, we fit the IR SED using two different dust emission models. The first is the library of <a name=\"InR48\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R48\">Draine et al. (2014)</a>, which is an extension of the <a name=\"InR47\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R47\">Draine &amp; Li (2007)</a> dust emission model, while the second set of models is presented in <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R99\">Schreiber et al. (2018)</a>. As shown in Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#F10\">10</a>, both libraries provide a good fit to the data, with <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19-eq14.gif\"></span> of 2.94 and 3.77 for <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R99\">Schreiber et al. (2018)</a> and <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R48\">Draine et al. (2014)</a>, respectively. The <i>L</i><sub>IR</sub> obtained with the two libraries is log(<i>&#956;L</i>/<i>L</i><sub>&#8857;</sub>) = 14.03 (Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#T4\">4</a>). As a free parameter of the fit, the temperature obtained from the <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R99\">Schreiber et al. (2018)</a> model is 41.3 &#177; 1.2 K. The library of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R48\">Draine et al. (2014)</a> does not directly fit the temperature, but the parameter <i>U</i><sub>min</sub> can provide an approximation of the temperature through the formula derived by <a name=\"InR3\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R3\">Aniano et al. (2012)</a>, <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19-eq15.gif\"></span> K, leading to a temperature of 35.9 &#177; 9.7 K. At <i>z</i>&#8196;=&#8196;4.72, given the dust temperature measured, the Cosmological Microwave Background (CMB) should have a negligible impact on the <i>L</i><sub>IR</sub> of RV4 (<a name=\"InR33\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R33\">da Cunha et al. 2013</a>). From the SED fitting, we also estimate log(<i>&#956;M</i><sub>dust</sub>/<i>M</i><sub>&#8857;</sub>) = 10.03.</p>\n<p><a name=\"F10\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/F10.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19-fig10_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/F10.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 10.</span></a><p>IR SED modeling of RV4. The flux densities are not corrected from magnification. Black circles are the SPIRE data, while diamonds and triangle are the NIKA and VLA fluxes, respectively. The downward triangles indicate the non detection from PACS. The IR SED was fit using the IR libraries of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R99\">Schreiber et al. (2018)</a> (light blue) and <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2020/03/aa36727-19/aa36727-19.html#R48\">Draine et al. (2014)</a> (purple).
